PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 1 March 1986, of Mr Olof Palme, Prime Minister of Sweden.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 1 March 1986, of Mr Olof Palme, Prime Minister of Sweden, condemns the brutal act which took his life and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and the members of his family and to the Government and people of Sweden.

I am sure that all members of the Senate were shocked and saddened to hear of the murder of Mr Olof Palme. Such a criminal act should receive the strongest condemnation and I am sure that it has it from this House. Prime Minister Palme's tragic and untimely death was a great loss to Sweden and the world. He had served his country in various portfolios since 1963 and was Prime Minister for 11 years. In the Swedish context, notable for its tradition of peace and non-violence, the senseless futility of this act stands out all the more starkly. Sweden has lost an outstanding leader.

The Prime Minister, Mr Olof Palme, worked vigorously towards maintaining a strong economy, achieving full employment and safeguarding the welfare of the Swedish people. It was a notable feature of his leadership that his concern for economic and social justice did not end with the affairs of his own country. He brought the same passionate commitment to these ideals to bear on his approach to world affairs and did so, moreover, with a real depth of intellect. Olof Palme was a man devoted to promoting economic development, social justice and peace and he understood the interrelationship of these objectives. Mr Palme's global commitment to the democratic process and to the rights, freedoms and well-being of all people is attested by the policies which he adopted. His stand for fundamental human rights can be seen in his championing of the campaign against racism. He promoted a generous refugee policy, believing it to be an important expression of international humanitarian solidarity. He believed that rich nations should join in the struggle against poverty in order to achieve a more just world order.

Olof Palme was Vice-President of the Socialist International and led its working group on the southern Africa question. He was a member of the important Brandt commission which studied questions concerning the relationship between rich and poor nations. In November 1980 Mr Palme was appointed as representative of the United Nations Secretary-General to seek a peaceful solution to the Iraq-Iran conflict. He stood firm on Sweden's policy of neutrality and worked tirelessly to promote world peace and disarmament. Olof Palme's contribution to the international debate on arms control and disarmament won him wide acclaim during his chairmanship of the Commission on Disarmament and Security from 1980 to 1982.

He was an idealist without illusions. He recognised that general and complete disarmament was a long term objective which could only be achieved through patient and careful negotiations that took account of international security concerns-those of the United States and the Soviet Union in particular. Palme did not consider nuclear deterrence to be an acceptable permanent basis for international peace and stability, but he accepted that it was the only viable option as an interim security measure while arms control negotiations took place. The Australian Government's approach to arms control and disarmament shares many of the perspectives of the Palme report on these issues. Olof Palme also played a significant role in the setting up in 1984 of the conference on disarmament in Europe which aims to build confidence and reduce the risk of conflict between states in Europe. He firmly believed, as does the Australian Government, that questions of peace and disarmament in the nuclear age should be the concern of all nations and should not be left for the nuclear weapon states and the big powers alone to determine.

His passing is a great loss to all of us throughout the world, regardless of ideological divisions between those in the East and those in the West; regardless of economic divisions between the people of the North and those of the South. It is for his contribution to the noble goal of transcending such divisions which exist in this imperfect world that Olof Palme will be most widely remembered.

Senator Don Grimes, the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Community Services, will represent the Australian Government at Olof Palme's funeral, which is to be held in Stockholm on 15 March. Senator Grimes was a personal friend of the late Prime Minister, having met him on a number of occasions at meetings of the Socialist International. He is also known to Mr Palme's widow, Lisbeth. The attendance of Senator Grimes at the funeral is a mark of the deep respect which the Australian Government has for Olof Palme's achievements in the cause of world peace and social justice and of the friendship which Australia feels for the Government and people of Sweden.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I wish to support the expression of sorrow at the death of Olof Palme and the condemnation which was expressed by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) of the senseless act of violence which brought about his death. There was, I think, in the hearts of many Australians very deep sorrow at the tragic death of the Prime Minister of Sweden and there was a great deal of concern at the senseless act of violence which brought it about. Of course, it was totally unfitting that a man who had dedicated himself so completely to the pursuit of peace should die in such a violent way.

SPEECH.PARA: My own regret at hearing the news was immediately followed by the realisation that for many members of the present Government Mr Palme had particular significance as a leading European socialist and as a leader of the Socialist International. I am very pleased that Senator Grimes, who was a particular friend of Mr Palme, is able to represent the Australian Government and the Australian people at the funeral. It occurs to me that in many respects Mr Palme was what many in the present Government would wish to be in the very substantial programs which he was part of implementing over many years in his own country. I was struck when I was reading something of him to find that his expression on gaining government after a fairly radical introduction to politics as a student and otherwise was: `The soup will not be eaten as hot as it is cooked'. I thought that perhaps that was an experience which many present Ministers would have had in terms of current politics.

The Opposition, whilst acknowledging that at times there were differences between its own approach to the pursuit of peace and that put forward by Mr Palme both domestically and on the international stage, acknowledges his continuous pursuit of that great objective, acknowledges that in many respects he embraced ideas which are central to our own thinking, including the maintenance of a strong defence force for his own country and for the temporary importance of the deterrence in maintaining peace. The main object of speaking today is simply to express the very deep regret which the Opposition has at this most untimely death and which we share with all members of the Government at this very unhappy time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in their expressions of sympathy for and outrage at the murder perpetrated in the friendly and neutral country of Sweden. Senator Button quite rightly has outlined many of the causes which Mr Palme embraced in his long career in politics. Some were issues with which many of us would agree, others were issues with which some of us might not necessarily agree. With a man of Mr Palme's calibre it is necessary to look behind the politics and to see the man. He was a man of great concern and compassion for his fellow human beings.

SPEECH.PARA: It is one of the world's tragedies that a man, a world leader and the leader of his nation, could not go about with his wife and mix among his people, could not go to such an innocuous event as the theatre, without being gunned down in such a cowardly fashion. On behalf of the members of the National Party of Australia I support the expressions of sympathy put by the Leader of the Government and the Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I would like to join my colleagues from other parties in expressing our sadness and regret at the death of Mr Olof Palme, and to extend our sympathy to the widow and children of a Prime Minister who was greatly respected. He was, as one headline put it, a leader who searched for a better world. In doing so, it would seem he acquired the affection and support of the majority of his compatriots, apart from a minority of apparently extreme right wing Swedes. His countrymen and women regarded him as a caring human being, as an humanitarian politician, and as a Prime Minister whose pursuit of a policy of armed neutrality had won Sweden respect on the world stage, while still managing to keep his country out of conflict with other nations including, of course, that most threatening neighbour, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

SPEECH.PARA: On the home front, Mr Palme's Social Democratic Party had put Sweden in the forefront of social reform by introducing policies that even his conservative opponents did not try to dismantle during their brief period of power between his two reigns as Prime Minister. More important, I suspect, to most Swedes was the fact that in the two periods when he was leader of their country he set Sweden firmly on the world stage as a country to respect for the way in which he handled its foreign policy. Olof Palme proved that it was possible to be neutral without endangering his country, to be critical of the United States' policies without being anti-American, and to be tough with Sweden's neighbours, the Russians, without making his country vulnerable to attack. His evenhandedness in the area of foreign policy is probably best indicated by the fact that he managed within a period of several years to anger both the Russians and the Americans by demonstrating, first of all, against the Russian invasion of Czechoslovakia in the late 1960s and, shortly afterwards, publicly denouncing the United States for its bombing of Vietnam. The latter caused the Americans to recall their ambassador for some time, and the former produced an angry response from the Russians.

That a man who was dedicated to promoting world peace, who was evenhanded in his criticism of those who promoted aggression, and who was forward looking in preparing his country for a sound economic future could be so cold-bloodedly and deliberately destroyed by a political opponent is, as the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, said a tragic irony. What struck me as most sickening about the whole affair was the enthusiasm of the celebration by certain elements of the Right in Sweden, who regarded Mr Palme's assassination as some kind of victory. Indeed, I understand, it was the revelry of some right wing students celebrating Olof Palme's death with champagne at Chamonix which led to his teenage son first learning of his father's assassination.

The world is, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, said, rightly shocked and saddened at Mr Palme's death and with it the silencing of one of the world's most intelligent and outspoken proponents of peace. Again, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, I extend our sympathy to a country which has lost a caring and just leader, and our condolences to his family in the sad and tragic loss of a loving husband and father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a world where every minute of every day someone dies an unnecessary and tragic death, it is very saddening that today we should be moving a motion of condolence on the death of Olof Palme who, as Senator Button has said, has been known to me for some time. He was the Leader of the Social Democratic Labor Party in Sweden, the party with the longest continuous history in that part of the world, an extraordinary party which was formed in 1889 yet Olof Palme was only its fourth Leader. When he became Prime Minister of Sweden he was the youngest head of state in Europe.

SPEECH.PARA: Olof Palme came from a very small country yet he was internationally extremely well known, as anyone reading the newspapers after his death would have realised. He was an extremely well known and respected international statesman, despite the fact that he was not a physically imposing man, despite the fact that he came from a very small country and despite the fact that over the years, as Senator Haines has pointed out, he frequently irked both of the super-powers. There are very few people who have been described as revisionists, as those in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics are want to call people who are social democrats or democratic socialists, and at the same time are described, as Jeane Kirkpatrick described him, as a deliverer of revolution in the world.

Olof Palme laboured long and hard to put across three messages. The first was the right of individuals, whoever or wherever they are, to be free to take part in the decisions which affect their lives and to have the right to stand up and speak for others. Secondly, he stood very firmly for the right of small nations to stand up for their rights and the right of others to demand of the super-powers that they be taken notice of, and to do that as frequently as possible but at the same time to have the capacity to retain the security of their own nations. He did that all his political life. The third thing for which he fought was peace. As Senator Button and Senator Chaney have pointed out, he worked in the area of disarmament, yet while fighting vigorously against nuclear weapons-indeed, while fighting vigorously for disarmament generally-he recognised that in the case of his country and other European countries there was a necessity, as he and his Party saw it, for the peaceful use of nuclear power. As a result of that he lost two elections, but that did not stop him from working very hard internationally and nationally for a better, more equal and equitable world. He and his Party in Sweden have had the capacity to develop a welfare state in a country which provides levels of excellence in manufacturing, design and development for which it is world recognised and at the same time have maintained a very low unemployment rate, a low inflation rate and economic growth. It is a secret that many people in the West, as Senator Chaney has said, would like to know.

I knew Olof Palme as Vice-President of the Socialist International. At the Socialist International he was so respected that whenever he spoke there was silence. In speaking he combined the vigour and earnestness of someone who felt very strongly about the subject on which he was speaking with a continuous call for reason on behalf of those who were taking different views. I remember that he played a very important role in a debate in Denmark where the Australians-Gough Whitlam and I-and the French were having a considerable disagreement about what happened in the South Pacific. Olof Palme had the capacity to agree with us but placate the French so that they did not actually walk out on that occasion as they had done in the past. Willy Brandt, who was a personal friend of his, said:
I do not know how the gap can be filled that has been left by the violent death of Olof Palme. But I do know that we shall honour him best by continuing his work.

I think those words could be well directed not only at members of social democratic and democratic socialist parties throughout the world but to all of us who believe in democracy and who strive within the democratic system.

I will go to Stockholm on Saturday with sadness but with some pride that I can represent my Party and, I hope, this whole country at the funeral. I think it is a measure of his respect that there will be some 12 Prime Ministers and heaven knows how many other heads of state there. Sweden has lost a great man; the world has lost a great man. His wife Lisbeth and his three sons have lost an honoured husband and father. I am glad that this Parliament has seen fit to pay respect in the way it has to this very great, very respected, very peaceful and loving man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —All those who have been earnest students in the last decade or more in the search for peace and disarmament will know of Olof Palme and his work. Some might differ in detail regarding the mechanisms of his pronouncements and assertions, but one would have to recognise the sincerity of the man, indeed the quality of greatness which gave him a prominence in the world in this sphere. I personally was not privileged, as Senator Grimes was, to have met him but I have read much of his pronouncements. I have been a student of his chairmanship of conferences and of the Palme report. The world has seen a man from a nation that is non-aligned coming forward with vigorous ideas, willing to test those ideas and willing to accept from others a verdict that is right or wrong, but pursuing them in what ought to be the real battlefield of peace-the conflict of ideas as to the right mechanisms to achieve peace and not the conflict of force. One can argue about mechanisms, and that ought to be the argument of a freedom loving country, but one does not emphasise one's arguments with the use of force. As others have said so well today: What a tragedy, what a tragic irony that in this International Year of Peace one of the great leaders for peace in this world should have fallen by violence. That is an enormous tragedy indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: Olof Palme came from a nation which, however small, is contributing mightily to the dialogue for world peace. It is true that if one is non-aligned one has more elastic side limits within which to manoeuvre. When one goes to conferences-whether it is United Nations conferences or the conference for disarmament in Geneva-one can see the great freedom that such countries have to express their views. I personally found great interest and great edification in talking to the ambassador for disarmament from Sweden when I visited Geneva. He expressed a view of a small country embattled by outward pressures, a country that was devoted to peace and whose leaders were giving leadership in this regard. There may have been ideological differences between a person such as Olof Palme with his broad ideology and me. I cannot find myself at difference with his goal, which was to achieve world peace with dignity and freedom. He recognised the pragmatism of that journey towards total disarmament, and towards that end I think we all share in his goal.

I want to add my voice, as one who has spent quite some years, as have others in this place, studying the pursuit for peace and disarmament, in acknowledging that Olof Palme was a national leader, an internationalist, a person who added very greatly to the dialogue for the pursuit of peace, whose immortality lies in his work. I think it was Christopher Wren's son who wrote on the northern door of St Paul's Cathedral-I think it was in Latin: `If you would seek his monument, look around you'. I think we can say, when we look at the United Nations, the Conference on Disarmament, or wherever in the dialogue for peace: `If you would seek Olof Palme's monument, look around you'. I add my tribute to his nation and to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also extend my sympathy to the Swedish people and Government and to the family of Olof Palme. He was a person of peace. He exemplified Sweden's place in the world-a prosperous yet caring society, a nation with a conscience and concern for the plight of a humanity in suffering. Olof Palme promoted and reflected his nation's concern in world affairs by combining a sense of moral idealism with considered Swedish pragmatism. As leader of the Social Democrats and Swedish Prime Minister for a decade, he committed his nation to a sophisticated form of corporatism in which state intervention was used not only to promote economic growth and efficiency, but also to promote justice and equity.

SPEECH.PARA: Internationally, Olof Palme promoted the link between wealth and equity by becoming a primary architect of his nation's commitment to both peace and justice issues. He committed Sweden to giving one of the highest aid percentages of any Western nation to help developing countries, and he often promoted the cause of justice, whether it was through seeking a solution to the problems of southern Africa or seeking a peaceful resolution of the conflicts in central America. I will not reiterate what other senators have said about his wonderful work in the field of nuclear disarmament.

The Swedish people have been profoundly shocked by the violent assassination of a person who worked for peace. As a note at the place where Mr Palme was gunned down said, who has killed our peace dove? His death is a tragic loss to Sweden in particular and to all people who nurture his ideals of a free, just and more peaceful world. Olof Palme will be remembered as one who dedicated his life to humanity in the cause of justice and peace.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate. In this session of Parliament the proposed Bill of Rights will come before the Senate to be debated.
We, the undersigned, would like to voice our protest at the proposed Bill.

1. Because of the haste and secrecy with which this legislation was passed through the House of Representatives despite the fact that it will adversely affect areas of immense importance to liberty and freedom and is contrary to the spirit of the Australian Constitution.

2. The Bill is based upon the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which has been rejected by both the United States of America and Great Britain but accepted by the Warsaw Pact countries. We therefore believe there is a potential threat to our national security through making treaties of this kind with foreign nations, many whom do not practice the principles that they have covenanted to uphold.

3. Because our Australian Constitution states that `whereas we the people' give you the government these rights, the Constitution limits the right and power of government. The proposed Bill of Rights reverses this totally and states that `we the government, give you the people these rights'. This totally reverses the nature of government in this country.
4. Our rights and the principles of freedom are now protected by current legislation, Common law and the present Constitution.
5. Because it transfers the power of interpretation of legislation from the Parliament of Australia (the democratically elected institution) to the Courts (unelected body of people).

6. Because the Bill of Rights will be administrated by the Human Rights Commission which is an unelected body of people with powers which are outside and not subject to the normal processes of law-no appeal, closed hearings, no legal representation.

7. That the implementation of the legislation through a process of new educational initiatives will result in the centralised control of education and this will inevitably lead to the destruction of States' rights and just as inevitably the centralised control, by government, on human behaviour.
We therefore request that you vote to reject this proposed Bill of Rights in any shape or form being introduced in Australia.
Yours humbly.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That certain Trade Unions are currently forcing employers and employees to join union-controlled Superannuation schemes through industrial blackmail, thereby extending the Unions' economic power and at the same time infringing individual rights.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
(i) Guarantee that Occupational Superannuation is a matter of individual choice
(ii) Declare illegal industrial standover tactics which force people to join superannuation schemes controlled by, or sponsored by, trade unions
(iii) Protect those companies and their employees who establish their own superannuation arrangements at the enterprise level
(iv) Ensure that union or industry-based schemes are not disguised pay rises by providing that employees must also make contributions.
(v) Provide that control of the funds of such schemes is vested in the elected representative of the contributors to those schemes
(vi) Oppose any backdoor attempts at achieving compulsory unionism.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
They adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG, and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video-cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Evans is currently Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. Mr Hayden will return to Canberra from the Philippines tomorrow.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, follows earlier questions and his answers on the car industry, the most recent being on 20 February. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that since that time the Vehicle Builders Union has estimated that up to 15,000 jobs could be lost in the industry because of the Government's proposed tax. Given that new vehicle registrations in January were 13 per cent lower than 12 months ago and that the industry faces a difficult year because of factors such as the currency depreciation, unleaded petrol and changes to sales tax, and in the light of the Government's refusal to abandon the fringe benefits tax, has the Government yet decided on any changes or modifications to the Treasurer's original proposal?
—The answer to the honourable senator's question is no, but as soon as we decide we will let him know.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry a question about forestry activities in Tasmania, highlighted by the appalling attitude of the Gray Liberal Government and the forestry companies to conservationists protesting at Farmhouse Creek. It is a fact that the Premier of Tasmania is displaying an extraordinary lack of co-operation and is still refusing to sign the agreement with the Federal Government for the export woodchip industry beyond 1988 in the terms to which he agreed towards the end of last year? In view of Mr Gray's intransigence and his going back on his word now that the State election is out of the road, will the Minister for Primary Industry agree that the time has come to tell the Premier that, if he is going to maintain that attitude, all bets are off and that the Commonwealth will now take a much tougher position and insist on more stringent conditions on all woodchip exports instead of the reasonable compromise of last year so that our responsibility to protect the National Estate as well as jobs is fulfilled?

—I am advised that the view of Mr Kerin on this matter is that it shows how ineffective is the politics of confrontation as practised by Premier Gray and mountebanks like Dr Bob Brown and Senator Sanders, and one could probably add some of the companies involved. If the Tasmanian Government continues to play the Premier's confrontationist, States rights games, the Commonwealth will have no choice but to place stringent conditions on each and every woodchip export licence from 1988 onwards.

—I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy: In view of the continuing fall in world oil prices since the determination which was announced by the Government to take effect from 1 March, which would of course result in a further fall in the petrol prices Australian motorists are paying, will the Government, as foreshadowed in that statement, move to an earlier and more flexible adjustment of its determination of oil prices and not wait until 1 May, which is the next one scheduled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that in Mr Keating's and my joint statement of 24 February we said on behalf of the Government that we had decided to retain our regular two-monthly reviews of import parity pricing but that the Government would keep, as Senator Durack said, that oil market situation under close review and would act if an earlier review of the import parity price seemed desirable. It is also the case, to fill in the figures, that the 1 March IPP was based on a base price of $US16.77 and that the world oil market has further weakened since then, with the basket used to calculate that price now in the $US12 to $US13 range, which, if fully passed on, would involve another loss to Government revenue of the order of $500m to $600m and an associated drop at the petrol pump of around another 3c to 4c a litre-not another 10c or 11c a litre as I have heard in some rather extraordinary speculation. The situation is that it is simply not yet clear whether this fall will be sustained such that an IPP adjustment earlier than 1 May becomes obviously necessary.

ANSWER.PARA: I can say no more at this stage other than that the Government intends to keep monitoring the situation very closely to keep the prices under review. We will make a decision later this month as to whether or not to review them earlier than would otherwise be the case, especially in the light of developments at the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting scheduled to take place in Geneva next week which, it seems, will be followed by a meeting with a number of non-OPEC producers. It is perfectly possible, though not necessarily likely, that in the aftermath of that production decisions will be made which will change the whole price situation quite fundamentally once again. So against the background of that kind of day to day and week to week uncertainty, we are not anxious to rush to judgment as to whether any earlier review is necessary, but, as I said, we will certainly keep monitoring the situation closely.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Aviation been drawn to the recent report of a task force initiated by the Sydney Chamber of Commerce urging that a third runway be built at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport? If so, what response does the Government propose to make?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that all senators would be aware of the report commissioned by the Sydney Chamber of Commerce designed to put pressure upon the Australian Government to provide a third runway at Mascot and so contribute, as the report suggests, to an easing of the traffic problem and an increase in tourism. I think Senator Morris would be aware that all of the councils in the southern part of Sydney, in the eastern suburbs, St George and the Sutherland shire, regardless of political make-up, for the last 20 years have consistently opposed any suggestions that any further runways should be constructed at Kingsford-Smith airfield because of the traffic problems and the noise that would be associated with an increase in traffic.

ANSWER.PARA: It is 25 years since the Commonwealth Government was advised of the need for additional airport facilities in Sydney. For 25 years successive governments, particularly Liberal-National Party governments, have hedged on making the important decision about a second international airport in Sydney. The report that has been put out by the Sydney Chamber of Commerce ignores the basic fact that an additional airport should be constructed. This Government has bitten the bullet. It has made the decision to build a new airport at Badgerys Creek. The Minister for Aviation, whom I represent in the Senate, has indicated that a third runway is not necessary and will not be built and that the Government's decision to select a site at Badgerys Creek will put an end to the dithering and procrastination that have gone on for the last 25 years. I would suggest that the self-appointed experts who do not understand or comprehend the basic problems associated with air movements in our capital cities, particularly in Sydney which is the major international airport, might well leave their views to the professionals and to those whose responsibility it is to plan air traffic movements in our country.

There is plenty of capacity remaining at Kingsford-Smith Airport and there is no possibility at all that the Government will act upon the report commissioned by the Sydney Chamber of Commerce. While the Government recognises that Badgerys Creek is a long way from construction and completion-the land has only just been acquired-it is taking certain steps to improve the airport capacity at Mascot. New terminal facilities will be provided and new taxi-ing improvements will be made at the airport to make up for the neglect of past years. I assure Senator Morris that the concerns of local government and residents in that region prompted the Government to make the decision to go to Badgerys Creek.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the strong stand taken by the Government on the Franklin Dam issue, will the Hawke Government now act immediately to protect the National Estate areas of Tasmania from woodchipping and logging, particularly as Senator Walsh has indicated today that such action is contemplated in the future?

—The answer given by Senator Walsh encompasses the only sort of response that I can make to that question. I understood Senator Walsh's answer to be that, insofar as the issuing of woodchip licences in 1988 and beyond is concerned, the Government would have to take account of the position adopted by the Tasmanian Government. That is the major question at issue. I will certainly refer Senator Sanders's question to the Prime Minister and see whether he has anything to add to that answer.

—I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that the refusal of the Government to take the option of attaching significant conditions to export licences is due to a lack of political courage, not a lack of constitutional power?

—I have been asked whether the decision of the Government is due to a lack of political courage or, alternatively, to a lack of constitutional power. The fact of the matter is that the Government made a decision about this matter which is quite clear, however unpalatable it may be to Senator Sanders. That decision was made not with either of the considerations which Senator Sanders puts in my mind by his supplementary question. That decision has been made and Senator Sanders can characterise it as he likes, but that is not the subject of a legitimate question, in my opinion.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer to a national study into the situation of mothers who relinquish their children. Is the Minister aware that the study confirms that relinquishing mothers continue to suffer from lack of professional and family support? Is the Minister aware that nearly all research into adoption has concentrated only on the placed child and the adoptive parents? Will the Minister agree to investigate the matter further and ensure that the needs of relinquishing mothers, especially follow-up health care, are not overlooked?

—I am not aware directly of the report referred to by Senator Elstob. I am aware, however, that in recent times there has been some concern that mothers who relinquish their children are not being cared for as adequately as they might be. I will refer the report and the matter to the Minister for Health with the intention of getting an early answer for Senator Elstob in an attempt to see whether we can ensure that conditions improve.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education. I refer the Minister to the present situation regarding the payment of both the unemployment benefit and the tertiary education allowance. Can the Minister explain why a young person living at home and receiving the unemployment benefit can actually receive more than a sister or brother, also living at home, who is receiving a tertiary allowance benefit because of further study? Does this not seem to be a strange situation in which the unemployed person receives the greater benefit for staying at home and doing nothing while the person trying to further his or her career has to scrape to feed or clothe himself or herself? Is this not a case of destroying the incentive for further education while at the same time encouraging young people to go on the dole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly true that when our Government came to office in March 1983 there was a substantial gap between the allowance paid to a student who was eligible for the tertiary education allowance and the unemployment benefit. Since that time our Government has developed a common allowance so that this year, for example, the gap has been significantly closed and after another two years the levels should be the same. I agree with the implication in Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question that it is very discouraging for young people from poorer families to undertake tertiary studies when in doing that they actually get less support than they would if they were in the labour market looking for a job.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not agree, of course, that unemployment benefits are paid to young people to sit at home and do nothing. They ought to be looking for jobs. The work test administered by the Department of Social Security ought to be ensuring that they are indeed answering job applications and attending interviews. However, it certainly is my view that a gap between the two payments does act as a disincentive for students from poorer families. It is in recognition of that that our Government has taken steps to close those gaps so that by 1988 the levels of payment, on an age related basis, should be the same. Of course, at that stage it will still be the case that there will be a parental means test in regard to the education allowances but not in regard to unemployment benefit. That is in recognition of the fact that the unemployed young person theoretically is looking for a job and therefore is part of the labour market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs seen reports of proposals made by South Africa for the commencement of the implementation of the settlement plan for Namibia? What is the Australian Government's attitude towards the South African proposal, in particular the linking of Namibian independence to the withdrawal of Cuban forces in Angola?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has noted President Botha's announcement last week on 4 March that South Africa is prepared to begin implementing the United Nations Security Council Resolution 435 on 1 August if a firm and satisfactory agreement about the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola can be reached by then. Australia of course strongly supports the early independence of Namibia and takes the view that the United Nations Security Council resolution remains the only acceptable and agreed basis for an internationally recognised settlement in Namibia. We are deeply concerned that a Namibian settlement has been delayed for so long and that extraneous factors have so far prevented the early implementation of the United Nations settlement plan. Australia continues to be concerned that the linking of Namibia's independence to the withdrawal of Cuban forces remains an element in South African Government's latest proposal. This Government has consistently rejected that kind of linkage as a precondition for the implementation of Resolution 435.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government hopes that the South African Government's reaffirmation of its commitment to the United Nations settlement plan will lead to the unconditional implementation of Resolution 435 without delay. The Australian Government rejects any moves to pre-empt or bypass the United Nations settlement plan and would regard any such measures by the South African Government in relation to the establishment of constitutional bodies and the transfer of power in Namibia to be null and void. I mention finally that on 19 June last year Australia voted for the United Nations Security Council Resolution 566 on Namibia, which called on member states to consider the imposition of selective voluntary sanctions against South Africa should South Africa not give immediate effect to United Nations Security Council Resolution 435.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Trade aware that an export market development grant of some $25,000 was credited last year to a rat bag organisation known as the Creation Science Foundation Ltd? Has this so-called foundation, which is tax exempt as a religious organisation, written off $92,000 because of the failure of the company's investment agents-an amount equal to 60 per cent of the total donations which it received? Is the Minister concerned that export grants are being used to subsidise religious organisations, and particularly that such a bogus organisation can be a recipient of a large payment of public moneys, which is then wasted? Will he also draw to the attention of the Treasurer for review the tax exempt status of this body?

—I was unaware of any of those circumstances, which certainly as related by Senator Puplick have a degree of horror about them. I will convey the allegation of the tax status of this company to the Treasurer for investigation. I will ask the Minister for Trade whether he can have some inquiries made regarding the export market development grant to which Senator Puplick referred. There was also a question as to whether I would be concerned about this matter if the facts were correct. The answer to that question is, of course, yes.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and refer to the medication Tylenol, which has twice been subjected to adulteration by cyanide while on sale to the public at retail outlets in the United States of America. Is that drug still freely displayed for sale in Australian supermarkets? What assurances are available to the general public from the Federal Government that the product is safe from any similar action in Australia?

—Tylenol was available in Australia but only in a limited area-northern New South Wales and, I think, Queensland. It was available in Australia in individually packed blister packages, so any attempt to contaminate the capsules in this country without its being obvious to the consumer would have been almost impossible. However, the product sponsor has decided to withdraw the capsules world-wide, and this withdrawal began in February in Australia. I think the action was aimed more at consumer confidence for the company than at safety considerations but, still, the substance is being progressively removed, despite the extreme unlikelihood of any contamination in this country. I believe we will not see a repetition of the unfortunate American experience.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation and refer to the decision of the Government to construct a new airport at Badgerys Creek. I accept that the questions are relevant and that the guidelines ought to be examined by the Department of Aviation, but they are matters which surely come within the province of the Minister to determine and I will draw his attention to them

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs received representations from the Professional Officers Association of Queensland to refuse visas for overseas teachers invited by the Queensland Government to teach in Queensland technical and further education colleges? Does the Association argue that the Queensland Government has made no real attempt to review its TAFE teacher training, recruitment and retention policies? Has the Department received any request from the Queensland Government that overseas teachers be permitted to take up positions in Queensland TAFE colleges? If so, how many positions are involved and what has been the Department's response to the request?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that the Professional Officers Association, on behalf of Queensland TAFE teachers, wrote to the Minister on 21 February requesting that the Department not proceed with visa issues to any nominees until the Queensland Government agreed to discuss the proposal with them. The Professional Officers Association claimed that insufficient efforts were being made by the Queensland Government to train and retain TAFE teachers and that locally trained teachers were available.

ANSWER.PARA: The Queensland Department of Education approached the Department in early February regarding the entry of some 50 tertiary and further education teachers under the employer nomination scheme for teaching courses associated with the hospitality industry. However, since then the Queensland Government has lodged only one nomination and this nomination has not been approved. Some employer nomination scheme requirements are still to be met. For example, the Queensland Department is still to demonstrate that it has a commitment to training local teachers rather than relying on overseas recruitment. The nomination will not be approved unless the outstanding requirements are met by the Queensland Department. At the time of the writing of this brief there had been only one application and that has been rejected for the reasons I have given.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and follows the question asked of him earlier by Senator Chaney concerning the Government's fringe benefits tax proposals for the motor vehicle industry. Is the Minister aware that the huge devaluation of the Australian dollar over the past 15 months has significantly increased the price of imported vehicles and components for locally manufactured vehicles and has thereby made the industry's compliance with the local content rules of the Government's car plan increasingly difficult? Is it a fact that the fringe benefits tax is likely to have the effect of reducing the average size of the motor vehicle fleet in Australia and that, because the imported content of smaller vehicles is greater than it is for larger vehicles, this will make it even more difficult for the local industry to comply with the Government's car plan? How does the Government propose to resolve the difficulties for the motor vehicle industry which the contradiction between the Treasurer's economic and taxation policies and the Minister's car plan has caused?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware that the devaluation has substantially increased the price of imported motor vehicles and the price of a number of components used in the Australian manufacturing industry. The price increases for components have led to considerable problems for some companies, and one in particular.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked whether the fringe benefits tax if applied in its suggested form would result in what the industry calls down-scaling; that is to say, lead to lesser use of the medium to larger size cars. That depends very much on the rates which are struck in respect of various mileages for cars. It is too early to make a final determination on the effects of a fringe benefits tax on down-sizing until one looks at the final form of the fringe benefits tax.

I am also asked whether the effects of the devaluation would lead to serious problems for companies in terms of the local content element of the plan. I think the answer to that question is yes. I have asked the Automotive Industry Authority to consult with the industry and to make recommendations to me about that matter in the near future. I have had discussions with the Authority already on that question and I suspect that we will be in a position to make an announcement about that quite shortly.
Senator Short concluded by asking how the various differences between the policies espoused by the Treasurer and the elements of the car plan will be resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contradictory policies.

—Yes, but I think with respect that is a little confusing because a number of policies, some of which the honourable senator has mentioned, or a number of impacts on the car plan other than the fringe benefits tax, would affect the viability in the long term. I think the question of the local content problem can be resolved. I hope that the question of down-sizing can be resolved. I would regard each of those matters as important, and an announcement will be made as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that at the Australian Labor Party National Women's Conference in January concern was expressed about the level of care and support available for older women, including funding of research into the diseases of aging, such as osteoporosis and Alzheimer's disease? Since a high proportion of older women are entitled to medical treatment and services through the repatriation system, can the Minister outline what steps are being taken and contemplated to improve the level of care available to them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that concern was expressed at the Labor Women's Conference about the problems of aging persons in the community generally and specifically as those problems related to my Department, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, which, through the Repatriation Commission, operates nine repatriation hospitals all of which can be largely described as hospitals providing care for aging persons. The average age of veterans is 67 years, so most of the patients would be in the aged group. The repatriation hospitals will look after aging people.

ANSWER.PARA: We have recently extended a number of services and provided new facilities to meet the sort of problem to which Senator Zakharov refers. Since this Government took office three years ago, over $100m has been spent in our repatriation hospitals to bring them up to modern standards and fit them out with the latest equipment. Most of the equipment will provide care for aged people and will provide those beneficiaries with the best possible care. Another $50m is committed to complete those particular works and to buy the latest equipment.

Expert staff has been encouraged to continue with research by funding, which has been increased by $270,000 in the last financial year. Twenty persons are employed specifically in this area. Topics under investigation by the staff include fluid balance, diabetics, the effects of vitamin A on cancer cells, thrombosis, Alzheimer's disease, senility, malaria and osteoporosis, which Senator Zakharov referred to, as well as respiratory and bowel conditions, which are common problems facing the aged. Of course, the general problems facing aged persons are matters for the State public hospital systems which provide similar types of services and facilities.

There are 70,000 elderly women who are entitled to treatment by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, either because of their own war service or because they are war widows. They benefit directly from the expertise of Veterans' Affairs doctors and specialists who are employed in the repatriation hospital system. The basis of our experience in that area is then disseminated by the contribution of articles to medical journals. I think one can say that there is a general concern by the Government, at both Commonwealth and State level. We do whatever we can, having regard to the financial resources available to us, to provide the best possible care for persons in the aged category.

(3) Will the Treasurer make a statement explaining-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator is making his question very long. He is giving a lot of information. I suggest that he come to the point.
—Senator Evans went on to ask whether--

That is, of course, one of the things on which this Government has been keenest and swiftest to move.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health been drawn to newspaper reports today about the Australian Medical Association urging doctors to `cease bulk billing and ignore fees set by the Federal Government'? What are the consequences of the AMA and its 18,000 members following the above advice? Will it mean increased costs to individual patients-I am presuming that doctors are not planning to reduce their fees-and what are the implications for Medicare and the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Medical Association made that call in a statement that it put out announcing that it would refuse to participate in the 1986 medical fees inquiry. In this extraordinary statement the AMA claimed on the one hand that rebates paid for services provided by general practitioners to pensioners and others were too low. Yet, on the other hand, it refuses to participate in an inquiry to look at those fees. From memory I think it had been willing to participate in this arrangement since 1966. In fact, I think in the last two years medical fees as a result of the inquiry have increased by something over 16 per cent. These increases are decided on as a result of the independent annual reviews that are carried out by Mr McKenzie.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not clear from the statement put out by the Australian Medical Association just why this year it wants to take its bat and ball and go home. The AMA claims that it has made this decision because the inquiry has been delayed. However, it knew of and was consulted about those delays by the Minister for Health and the Department of Health. The main reason for the delays was deciding what the terms of reference would be. Now that that has been decided-and it is my understanding that the AMA has not too much complaint about the terms of reference-it is difficult to understand why it will not take part in the inquiry. It may be that it is unwilling to let a proper arbitral body look at the fees that its members charge.

Of course, one of the difficulties facing the medical profession is that there is a much increased number of medical practitioners in this country. In particular, we have a greatly increased number of general practitioners. It is quite interesting to drive around Sydney, particularly at weekends, and find surgeries with lights on at night. Surgeries are open all day. It is almost like having Kentucky Fried GPs around the place. I assume that that is a result of increased numbers. The thing that fascinates me about some of my medical colleagues is that they are the greatest arguers for market forces to control industry until those forces affect their own industry. It seems to me that the large numbers of medical practitioners and GPs want to maintain or actually increase their relatively high fees and maintain their income despite the fact that there are many more of them per patient than there used to be. That position, of course, cannot be sustained. As my colleague Dr Blewett has said, if medical practitioners want a guaranteed income, the Government is certainly happy to talk to them about the salaried medical service and about getting more of them into a salaried medical service.

I think it is a bit unfortunate that the medical profession has taken this attitude. If its members are unwilling to go before a properly constituted arbitration system, if they wish to go ahead charging fees but, in particular, if they wish to do what the AMA wants them to do-and that is stop the time honoured tradition of charging pensioners only the standard pensioner fee-of course there will be increased costs to some patients and some considerable disability to some patients. There will be increased costs to the health service generally in this country, which cannot be justified. Governments of any political persuasion under those circumstances would be forced to take action as a result of irresponsible activity like that, but I think we will wait and see whether good sense prevails in the medical profession in the next few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the Government endorse the view expressed by the Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Butler, that we would not waste our time on an empty unilateral gesture and that such a moratorium is unverifiable, even though it is supported by such an eminent group as International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War which received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1985, and even though Mr Butler now supports establishing an international verification agency because he believes that verification is capable of solution at a technical rather than a political level? I refer again to the first part of my question which I am now asking for the third time, and I am seeking a direct answer. If the Government has done nothing to persuade a positive response to the Soviet moratorium, which will soon expire, I challenge it to have the guts to say so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a pretty heavy question for a Quaker, as Senator Walsh just reminded me. The Government's position on the Soviet Union's moratorium on nuclear testing was conveyed in an answer to an earlier question without notice which I received from Senator Vallentine and which I had incorporated into Hansard on 20 February 1986. The relevant part of that answer ran as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia welcomes any interruption of the nuclear testing programs. However, Australia's pre-eminent objective in this field remains a mutually agreed comprehensive test ban treaty that would be legally binding, effectively verified and consequently durable. Australia does not regard moratoria as a substitute for the concrete steps that need to be taken to make possible the conclusion of a comprehensive test ban treaty. Australia has and will continue to urge all countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, to be sufficiently flexible to allow work on those concrete steps or building blocks to get underway.

As that answer clearly states, Australia welcomes any interruption in nuclear testing programs. But a moratorium is not the Australian objective in this field. Our objective is a comprehensive test ban treaty. The long history of the quest for an end to nuclear testing clearly indicates to the Government that a comprehensive test ban treaty will simply not be concluded until it is demonstrated that compliance with such a ban can be verified with high confidence. The Government is seeking to have put in place the means of monitoring compliance and in this way to put beyond doubt the capacity to verify compliance with a comprehensive test ban treaty.

As to the reference to Mr Butler's remarks, I have not seen a formal record of the comments to which Senator Vallentine refers, but if he has been reported accurately, those remarks, when looked at against the background of the Government's policy and the responses that I have indicated, are clearly not inconsistent with the thrust of that policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of a recent speech by Dr Keith Boardman, the Chairman of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, to the Australian Industrial Research Group's symposium in Adelaide, in which he expressed a growing concern that takeovers had reached a point where they were acting against the national interest and that long term industrial growth was being sacrificed for short term corporate survival, including the threat that that imposes on research and development? Ltd by Mr Holmes a Court may cause a cutting off of the substantial BHP research and development program in order to add to short term, pre-tax profit? Thirdly, if so, is the Government acting irresponsibly in not presenting urgent legislation to the Parliament to act against raiders who borrow large sums at home and abroad and bank on some institutions selling out in order to show quick, short term results in a competitive situation? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen has asked a question in four parts. The first part is whether I am aware of a speech by Dr Keith Boardman at a symposium in Adelaide in which he expressed concern about takeovers. The answer to that part of the question is yes; I was at the same seminar. He then asked whether I was aware that Sir James Balderstone had expressed concern about the fact that if a Holmes a Court takeover of BHP is successful, Mr Holmes a Court may cut off the BHP research and development program in order to add to short term profit. Yes, I am aware of both those expressions of concern and of the views expressed by both those gentlemen.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I must say that I am appalled by Senator Missen's lack of care which is unusual in a person of his erudition, sensibility and care about the use of the English language. The third and fourth parts of the question simply do not follow from the first two parts. I was asked whether I was aware that these two gentlemen had views and, if so, would I not agree that the Government was acting irresponsibly. The Government has not acted irresponsibly in this matter. I think it has acted, in a sense, with great care. Generally the Government believes that takeovers of public companies are matters that are normally left to the judgment of the market, subject to compliance with the takeover code and other relevant legislation-a matter which is currently being tested, in the interests of shareholders, in an action in the Supreme Court of Victoria.

Senator Missen also raises the question of the revenue implications and the effects of negatively geared takeovers. I can inform him that although there are a number of facts which I could put to the Senate about this matter which would not encourage the view that Senator Missen implies in his question, the Government is examining those matters and a decision will be taken in due course. The Government is examining those matters in the context of the implications for companies generally, which was the point raised by Dr Keith Boardman. Dr Boardman did not make his comments, as I understand them, in the context of the current BHP matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that he did.

—No, I know the honourable senator did not and I am not suggesting that. In general, the Government will look at those matters and the Treasurer will bring forward a submission to Cabinet on those issues in the near future. Having said that, let me just return to the anxiety expressed by Senator Missen and the view expressed by Sir James Balderstone. I personally take the view-and I believe the Government does too-that it is not the Government's business to arbitrate in competing claims, some of them somewhat wild, made by protagonists in a company takeover which would not be described as friendly. Things have been said on both sides and I do not think it is the Government's function to arbitrate in those matters. However, the Government saw as its function the need to be satisfied in respect of a number of matters relating to the proposed takeover of BHP by Mr Holmes a Court.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government identified two interests which were of concern to the Commonwealth and to taxpayers. The second was the question of any adverse effects on the revenue base to which I have already referred. Because the Government was concerned about those matters in the particular case relating to BHP, it went to endless trouble to try to satisfy itself about those matters and, to the best of its ability, it has done so.
