DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Remote Commercial Television Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is the third report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on the establishment of remote commercial television services. This report covers a region which takes in most of south-east Australia throughout the States of New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania. In particular it concerns those regions which presently are unserved or underserved by existing commercial television services. Unlike the areas covered in the previous reports which we have dealt with in this chamber-the first of which concerned itself with the south-west region of Western Australia and the second one with the remote north-east region of Queensland-this is an area in which there already is penetration to a certain degree by a certain number of television services. This is a zone where it is not so much a matter of there being no television services as a matter of there being limited television services. It is an area which is underserviced rather than unserviced. In New South Wales and Tasmania over 50 per cent of the geographic area is already served by existing commercial television stations; only about 20 per cent of the geographic area of Victoria is presently unserved. Therefore these remaining areas will be part of the remote community television service.

The decision of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is that the licence should be granted to Satellite South East Pty Ltd, which is a consortium made up of 12 existing broadcasters, each of whom hold an 8.33 per cent interest in Satellite South East Pty Ltd. The Tribunal has been adopting this as a general mechanism. Whereas in the south-west of Western Australia the decision was to provide the licence to the Golden West Network, which was in fact a sole operator, in the second report dealing with the remote north-east region of Queensland the licence was given to Queensland Satellite Television, which was a consortium of 11 companies. It is interesting to note that between the second and third reports the Tribunal has managed to bring down a unanimous report concerning the awarding of the licence whereas in the Queensland report there was in fact a dissenting opinion by one of the members of the Broadcasting Tribunal. Therefore it is pleasing to see that the process of the awarding of remote commercial television service licences continues.

However, it raises a number of matters which the Government has still failed to address. The first and most important of these is the extent to which these licences are to be integrated with remote area radio services. I believe that in a number of areas in fact we are jumping ahead to the provision of television services in advance of the provision of radio services, which I think should have been given priority. The second area which the Government is still failing to address is the ownership and control provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Act. This is an area which has been very much complicated by the entry of consortia into the granting of licences. The Government needs clearly to address the ownership and control provisions. I understand that in fact an investigation is under way but we have no details as to the parameters of that investigation or, indeed, its time-table. It is another area of continued indecision by the Government in critical areas of broadcasting and the provision of television services.

This report also gives me the opportunity to note the appointment of Ms Deirdre O'Connor as the new Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as successor to Mr David Jones, who is to take up an appointment to the Bench in Victoria. It gives me the opportunity to place on record my personal tribute to Mr Jones for having conducted the affairs of the Tribunal throughout a most difficult time with a considerable degree of skill-although I note that it is unfortunate during the last couple of years the extent to which the Tribunal has become nothing more than yet another lawyers' playground. I hope that Ms O'Connor has continued success in the very difficult task which faces the Tribunal in trying to get some sense and some rationality into the development of broadcasting services in Australia, which are clearly in need of major overhaul, and the Broadcasting and Television Act, which is clearly in need of a major rewrite. I shall look forward to future reports from the Tribunal at least attempting to come to grips with some of these matters once the Government gets off its collective backside and gives a bit of direction to the industry and to the Tribunal about the way in which it sees services developing in the future and, in particular, the use of new broadcasting technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Puplick for raising the subject of David Jones, the former Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, who has now become a County Court judge-the first solicitor in Victoria to achieve that honour. I think it is justly deserved. He is a man who brought a great deal of dignity and sense to the job as Tribunal Chairman. I wish to place that fact on record. I also wish the new Chairman, Deidre O'Connor, all the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words on the third report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on remote commercial television services. As Senator Puplick said, this report deals with the south-east region. It grants the remote commercial television service licence for the south-east region to the regional consortium Satellite South East Pty Ltd. It is a consortium of a dozen existing regional television stations in the appropriate areas of Australia. As the report says, the licence has been granted on the basis that SSE has demonstrated that it is not a monopoly and that it has the technical, managerial and financial capabilities to operate the licence. I welcome the decision. I am familiar with some of the stations that go to make up the consortium and I believe that they are technically and in other ways a very fine group of stations and fully deserving of this licence for the south-east region although, as I understand, it is not a licence that will do other than merely provide a very valuable community service to the people in remote regions. The economic viability of such a licence is by no means an assured thing.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of points in the report to which I want to draw attention because I believe this report leads to other issues which still have to be resolved by the Government and which the Government has not yet addressed or turned its mind sufficiently towards. I draw the attention of the Senate to the conclusion contained in paragraph 5.19 on page 85 of the report, which states:

Thus it is apparent that the battle lines have again been drawn over program supply and distribution. The Networks take the position, with respect to programs for which they have the Australian rights (which generally is over half the programming televised by the regional stations), that those programs will not be available to regional stations where they propose as part of the delivery chain to use RCTS as an SPS.

SPS, of course, is a satellite programming service. That is an important statement, I believe. It contrasts very sharply with the attitude of the regional television stations that they should be allowed to negotiate program rights independent of distribution, and so after negotiating a fair commercial price for their rights they can make their own plans so far as distribution is concerned. The other paragraph of the report to which I draw attention is paragraph 6.56 on page 101, which states:

The Tribunal draws attention to its conclusions in Chapter 5 on the issue of RCTS/SPS and program rights and distribution. The Tribunal believes that they are important issues to be addressed by the Government in its review of the ownership and control rules-
a matter to which Senator Puplick referred-
equalisation of services and regulation of networking.

We have a situation in which the Government is soon going to have to take some decisions that will have a major effect on television in this country questions of ownership and control, networking provisions, and the role and place in Australia of the networks compared with the regional television stations. I believe the Government has a major responsibility, when it does start looking at these matters and taking these decisions, to place full weight on the important role that the regional television network channels in Australia play in the overall context of television in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I rise to comment briefly on the Australian Trade Union Training Authority report for a number of reasons, not the least being some association of my own with the Authority in that I have been involved with the Authority in South Australia and have contributed briefly to some of the courses there. I recollect a very hamfisted piece of manoeuvering in the Senate last year on the occasion of this paper being tabled; as a result of a motion moved by Senator Lewis we were able to speak to this very report for, I think some two hours. So we have comprehensively reported on the Trade Union Training Authority in the past, and it is almost for old times sake that I feel we should recall to the Senate the 1984-85 report.

This is the tenth report from TUTA and it is very interesting to note that it has conducted 4,290 courses for over 80,000 trade unionists throughout Australia. That may not convey much to people, I suppose, but for those who have addressed the question of the training of people in the workforce and in the trade union movement, those figures represent a wonderful achievement and a tremendous gain, particularly on what was available prior to 1975 which was, in effect, nothing. The report details some of the events and some of the steps taken to address the difficulties, or perhaps the changes necessary, after an examination of the Trade Union Training Authority and its management structures. That process was underway, but it was not contained in last year's annual report. In this report we have some summary of the events, the procedures to that point, and statements by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) on how far the review and examination, and the decisions taken as a result of that review and examination, had been put in place, and they will shortly be implemented if they have not already been. The report states:
Mr Willis said that the government remained committed to the support of TUTA's work.
``An efficient, progressive and well-led trade union movement is of crucial importance to all Australians'', he said.

I think that goes very much to a dimension that sometimes is not acknowledged, the importance of exactly that-efficiency, progressivity and properly educated trade union leaders. We cannot possibly have adequate negotiations between one group that has all information or all responsibility, and one group that has most insufficient of any of that. I think the Trade Union Training Authority has contributed very much to a more focused and programmed educational program for trade unionists-certainly judging from the numbers, which have all increased. The report lists the number of people who have made use of the courses and the number has increased. It is quite clear that workers are taking advantage of the courses provided.

Another point which ties in to that appears under the heading of `Occupational Health & Safety'. The Executive Board's policy has always limited the amount of trade union training in occupational health and safety to about 15 per cent of the Authority's resources so as not to reduce education or training opportunities in other program areas. This report states that the actual achievement was 16.9 per cent. I suppose, overall, that is not too different from 15 per cent. The report goes on to say that, now we have a National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, it will and has started to provide resources both for the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry to promote and conduct health and safety training in industry. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that that resource goes not only to the ACTU but also to the CAI. The Government clearly acknowledges, through the funding from the Commission, the importance of properly trained occupational health and safety workers on both the management and workers side of the equation. It is no good, as I have said before when talking about the importance of trade union training in general, to have one significant part of a negotiating team clearly disadvantaged. I am pleased to be able to draw the attention of the Senate to the report. I recommend it. It is a small but very well printed little document that goes very much to acknowledging the changes that have happened in the Trade Union Training Authority. It goes into much more elaborate detail on the course work provided and the number of unionists who have taken up the opportunity to make use of those courses provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say something about the Australian Trade Union Training Authority report. The first annual report of the Accounting Standards Review Board, although only a small document, gives evidence of moves already under way to establish approved accounting standards in Australia. The Board was established in 1983 by the Ministerial council for Companies and Securities with the expressed purpose of establishing a system for the approval of accounting standards in accordance with predetermined criteria and also to impose obligations on directors and auditors of companies in respect of these particular standards. Directors of companies will be required to comply with an applicable approved accounting standard unless they can prove that compliance with that standard would result in the records not showing a true and fair view of their financial transactions.

In the discharge of its functions the Board also has power to determine priorities in consideration of proposed accounting standards, to review and report on standards referred to it and to conduct public hearings and invite public submissions into any aspect of its public functions. It also has a number of other functions. The Accounting Standards Review Board to date has received several submissions from the Australian Accounting Research Foundation and the Australian Shareholders Association. It has set itself a target of exposing nine standards for comment and public scrutiny by the end of this year. These include accounting for leases, disclosure of revenue, accounting for goodwill and accounting for the revaluation of non-current assets.

I wish to raise one issue about the disclosure of revenue. Each year companies are required to prepare, among other documents, a balance sheet and a revenue statement. I believe that in preparing a revenue statement there is a recognised concept of matching costs with revenue applicable to that particular period. I therefore find it somewhat strange that the accounting profession has been so tardy in not requiring its members and companies to separate interest charges into two components-those relating to the fixed capital component and those relating to the working capital component. I think that the revenue statement should show only the proportion of the interest charge which is a cost for the period under review, such as increasing current assets or a charge in the working capital component. I believe that we should distinguish between that and the fixed component which shows interest charges which give rise to changes in the capital structure of the company and increase the fixed assets. This matter has received some comment of late in relation to taxation issues. I believe that the separation of interest charges should be given some consideration as part of the Board's exposure draft to ensure that there is a proper matching of costs with revenue, especially interest costs. Unless this separation of interest costs is made we will perpetuate the artificial distortions between the treatment of interests and dividends in company accounts.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I do not find in the report a list of inquiries that have been held into the various aspects of the building industry over the past decade, but such a list would be relevant so that we could see what has happened with all the inquiries that have taken place so far. About five years ago we had a housing cost inquiry. It was a lengthy inquiry which did a very good job. It produced three large volumes which sit on the shelf. To the best of my knowledge, not a thing transpired to change the situation in the house building industry.

The report refers to the question of non-government resources. I suppose we could take this to be a voluntary or compulsory taxation on users, but whichever way one expresses it that is what it is talking about. Frankly, I cannot see that just the collection and dissemination of information will change anything very much. It seems that the people who put together this report are placing a lot of faith in that aspect of it because it is probably the only aspect that has not been tried or recommended by a whole variety of other organisations and inquiries. That may well be partly as a result of the composition of the particular committee. It comprised very eminent people, but they may have been too eminent. DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF MOVABLE CULTURAL HERITAGE BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Ryan) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to protect Australia's heritage of cultural objects and to extend certain forms of protection to the cultural heritage of other nations. As a result of these steps, Australia will be able to accede to the 1970 UNESCO convention on the means of prohibiting and preventing the illicit import, export and transfer of ownership of cultural property.

All nations possess objects which illustrate in unique or significant ways there history and culture. In Australia's case some of these objects date back beyond recorded history to the deep roots of aboriginal life; others relate to the period of exploration and settlement and to the progressive growth over the last two hundred years of a distinctively Australian society.

In speaking of cultural objects I am not simply referring to works of art, although the cultural heritage obviously embraces paintings, prints, crafts, sculpture, manuscripts, books, furniture and other art objects. I am referring to the full range of cultural heritage material. This also includes stamps, coins, maps, military objects and technological objects, including machinery, scientific material, inventions, archaeological finds, artifacts from aboriginal life, Government records, important documents, photographs, films and television material.

Rare and valuable cultural objects are increasingly sought after by collectors. In recent decades a thriving international market has developed with high prices being paid for rare objects. In some instances systematic looting of cultural treasurers is known to be organised by black-market operators in the big buying centres. The loss of material has reached crisis level in certain countries, particularly in the Third World, which has already suffered depletion at the hands of explorers, colonists, traders and missionaries.

UNESCO has long been active in encouraging its member states to protect the finite and vulnerable evidence of their cultural histories. In 1970 UNESCO drew up a convention to deal with the question of illicit international trafficking in cultural treasures. Fifty-three nations have now become parties to this convention, which imposes treaty obligations to return important cultural objects illegally exported from other parties.

The definition of cultural material given in the convention is broad, embracing archaeology, pre-history, history, literature, art and science and includes the range of material which I mentioned a moment ago. Although its primary focus is on illegal international traffic, the convention proposes other forms of protection, including a national inventory of protected cultural property, support for collecting institutions, rules for curatorial conduct, educational measures, controls on antique dealers and supervision of archaeological sites.

Australia's decision to accede to the 1970 convention was announced by the Minister for Education to the general conference of UNESCO in Paris in October 1983. The Legislation before the house will put us in a position to do this.

These steps have been long advocated by our museums, galleries, libraries and archives. The States are big holders of cultural collections and have a direct interest in this matter. I have been anxious to ensure therefore that whatever steps the Commonwealth took should be acceptable to the States. The proposals embodied in the Bill have the support of the States.

Most of the protective measures set out in the 1970 convention have long been practised in Australia, both at Commonwealth and State levels. The Customs Act 1901 and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Heritage (Interim Protection) Act 1984 provide protection for certain categories of cultural material. The States and Territories have laws which affect the removal of objects from archaeological sites and regulate the operations of antique dealers. All governments in Australia support collecting institutions which fulfil many of the convention's objectives, namely conservation, security, presentation and public education. In general our record on protection of our cultural heritage is good and the responsibility is widely shared.

In deciding how to approach the matter of accession to the 1970 convention the Government has taken the view that the Commonwealth should not attempt to subsume or replace arrangements already in hand at state or local level. However there are certain steps which must be taken at Commonwealth level before accession and those steps are the subject of this Bill.
In summary the Bill provides for:

New export and import controls to regulate the movement of important cultural objects. This will enable the establishment of reciprocal arrangements with other countries for the return of illegally exported material.
A national heritage fund to help with the acquisition of important cultural objects prohibited from export and for associated purposes.
New Administrative arrangements to manage these Commonwealth initiatives and maintain liaison with the States.

Let me deal first with the export and import controls. I should say at the outset that the Government is not seeking to stop movement of all cultural material or even most of it. We are concerned only to see that those objects the export of which would constitute an irreparable loss to our cultural heritage remain in Australia.

The categories of material to be protected are outlined in clause 7 of the Bill. A national cultural heritage control list will be drawn up, setting out these categories in greater detail, together with the criteria by which export controls will be exercised. The criteria will include such factors as age, rarity, quality, monetary value and extent of inclusion in public collections. The control list will distinguish between class A objects, namely those objects so rare and important as to be considered inalienable and class B objects which in certain circumstances may be given an export permit.

Much of this material is already prohibited from export under the Customs Act and subject to seizure and forfeiture if an offence is committed. The relevant schedules of the Customs Act have been developed over many years, yet do not cover all categories of important cultural material. When the new control list is established the present regulations under the Customs Act will be appropriately amended. All the categories to be included in the control list will be prescribed by regulations, thus subject to parliamentary scrutiny. The control list will be widely circulated and people owning valuable objects will have every opportunity to inform themselves as to the nature of the export controls.

In drawing up the arrangements for Australia we have studied Canada's experience with similar legislation. There, in any given year, less than twenty objects are prevented from export. Most of these are bought for display in public institutions or for return to tribal museums or communities in the case of Indian material. I would expect the Australian experience to be somewhat similar.

The Act provides for strong sanctions against illegal export and attempted illegal export. Since we are concerned only with objects of great importance it is proper that people taking such objects out of the country without authority should be subject to heavy penalties.

An object which has been exported unlawfully will be immediately forfeited to the Crown, so that we may move at once to institute recovery proceedings overseas. In the case of attempted illegal export, the object will be seized and liable to forfeiture. However, the owner will have the right to seek recovery for possession through the courts.

Of course there will be certain instances in which international movement of important objects may be warranted for purposes of conservation, study, exhibition or display, or an owner may for a temporary period be residing in another country. In such circumstances conditional export permits may be issued.

Given the range of cultural material for which permits may be sought, it will be necessary to have access to expert advice. A register of expert examiners will be established, including institutions whose professional staff will provide this service and individuals from academic, commercial and other backgrounds.

If, despite the export controls, an important object is illegally exported from Australia and is subsequently found in a country which is already party to the 1970 convention, the Commonwealth will be able to seek the return of that material through official channels once Australia has become a party to the convention. This will occur as soon as possible after the Act is proclaimed.

The import controls will apply only to important cultural material which has been imported into Australia without the requisite export authorisation from the country of origin. There will be no search of incoming luggage or freight. The import controls exist solely to enable Australia to respond if an official complaint is received from a foreign government that an illegally exported object has been brought to Australia. If a foreign government does not consider an object sufficiently important to lodge such a complaint, then we do not consider ourselves as having an obligation to protect that country's cultural property on its behalf. Although these controls relate essentially to Australian's treaty obligations under the 1970 convention, they will also make it possible for the government to provide this form of protection to countries which may not yet be party to the convention.

An institution or individual buying an important cultural object from overseas will need to be satisfied that the requisite export authorisations have been issued in the country of origin. This is already the practice of all reputable collecting institutions and private collectors. In any case the interests of innocent third parties are safeguarded by the 1970 convention. A country requesting the return of an object is required by the convention to offer financial compensation to an innocent third party purchaser.

I made reference earlier to the National Cultural Heritage Fund. The decision to establish the fund addresses two important matters of principle. The first is to ensure that important objects of the National Heritage which are barred from export should be readily available to the Australian public. Where objects are refused export permits, they will be acquired wherever possible for display in a public collection. The Fund will help facilitate these acquisitions.

The second principle relates to the rights of owners. The Bill is designed to recognise an individual's right to enjoyment of property while establishing the nation's right to restrict the movement of that property where it represents an irreplaceable part of the cultural heritage. We realise that, by imposing export controls, we are in a sense intervening in the rights of individuals to dispose of property as they see fit. We therefore believe that a means should exist of helping an owner to reach a fair price on the local market for an object which he may have wished to sell internationally.

The administration of this Act will require close co-operation between Commonwealth and State departments and authorities. A Committee will be established to assist in the administration of the new arrangements. The Committee will advise on the establishment of the National Cultural Heritage Control List, maintenance of a register of expert examiners, advice on the operation of the export and import controls and on allocations from the fund. The Committee will also provide advice periodically on the general situation with regard to the Movable Cultural Heritage and on policy issues which may require resolution. It is intended that the Committee will operate in a flexible manner and will respond readily to special applications.

It is essential that the membership of the Committee should reflect the diverse professions with involvement in Cultural Heritage matters. I therefore propose to ensure that the membership of the Committee includes representatives of archives, museums, libraries and galleries, as well as universities, which hold large cultural collections. Other people will be appointed with an eye to relevant experience and access to the professional expertise which will be required to run the new arrangements efficiently.

The Committee will also include a nominee of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. This recognises that special provisions may be required for the protection of our unique Aboriginal heritage and in particular rare artworks or secret/sacred objects. I propose to consult on these matters with my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in order to ensure that the administrative arrangements will accommodate the particular needs of Aboriginal tradition and society.

The costs of implementing the legislation will not be great, approximately $50,000 for administrative costs for 1985-86, and approximately $200,000 for 1986-87. Both staff and costs will be accommodated within my existing departmental resources and approved portfolio targets. An important component of initial costs will be an educative program to inform the public of this protection to cultural heritage. The amount to be provided to the fund will be a matter for Government in the budget context.

Finally let me stress that the convention is not concerned with restitution of cultural property taken from this country in the past or brought here in past years from other countries without proper authority. The restitution of cultural property is the subject of other Unesco efforts, but it is not the subject of the 1970 convention nor the purpose of this legislation. Rather the concern is to draw a line across history to ensure that, in future years, transfers of important and valuable cultural objects from one country to another take place in a legal and orderly fashion and that sanctions imposed will discourage illicit trafficking in cultural material. People all over the world are becoming increasingly aware of the precious and finite nature of their cultural heritage. Australians are now more conscious of the distinctive experiences and values of their national life. Those objects which uniquely represent that heritage should, wherever possible, remain in Australia for Australians to enjoy. There are too many countries whose citizens have to travel to museums and galleries in other lands in order to see the vestiges of their national heritage. We cannot allow this to happen to Australia. This legislation is designed to ensure that it does not happen.
Mr President, I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC PROSECUTIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Ryan) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill provides for amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983. The amendments arise from the experience of the operation of the Act since it came into effect on 5 March 1984.

The amendments clarify certain functions and powers of the Director as well as provide amendments to the existing Act where the existing provisions have required review since the Act came into effect.

Clause 3 of the Bill clarifies the circumstances in which the Director is authorised to present indictments in respect of offences not included in the committal order made by the magistrate. The amendments provide that, where a committal order is made in respect of one or more offences, the Director is authorised to present an indictment in respect of:-
(a) any other offence for which a person was examined (that is, the subject of the committal proceedings) but not committed for trial; or
(b) any other offence founded on facts or evidence disclosed in the course of the committal proceedings.

In addition, the amendments provide that the Director is authorised to present an indictment where no committal order has been made provided the defendant consents. However, except in the circumstances described, the Director is not authorised to present an indictment where no committal order was made at all or for an offence not included in the committal order. Accordingly, the effect of these amendments is that the Attorney-General will decide whether an indictment should be presented where no committal proceedings have been conducted, except where the defendant consents to an indictment being presented in such circumstances, or no committal order made.

Pursuant to this clause, sub-section 6 (3) of the Principal Act is also amended to make it clear that the operation of an instrument referred to in sub-section 6 (3) does not depend upon publication in the Gazette. The amendment will also permit the delaying of gazettal where public gazettal in relation to a particular person may prejudice the investigation of that person.

Clause 4 of the Bill amends section 9 of the Principal Act to provide that the Director may act as counsel or solicitor for an authority of the Commonwealth where that authority is a party to a proceeding in respect of a matter-
(a) that has arisen out of, or is connected with, the performance of any of the functions of the Director; or
(b) that may result in the performance by the Director of such a function.

This amendment will enable the Director to act on behalf of persons who may be the subject of civil proceedings in connection with matters in which the Director has advised or may advise. An example of such a situation is where the issue of a search warrant has been challenged.

Clause 5 of the Bill inserts a new section 15A to the Principal Act to permit police prosecutors to represent the Director in remote localities in proceedings for summary conviction of a person or in connection with formal matters related to committal proceedings. The purpose of the amendment is to avoid the cost and expense of sending the director's legal staff to remote localities for relatively minor hearings.

In relation to the amendment proposed in clause 6 of the Bill, provision was made in the civil remedies amendments to the Act, by virtue of the Director of Public Prosecutions Amendment Act 1985, for the prohibition of particular evidence or information in proceedings for civil remedies referred to in those amendments. The new sub-section 16A (1A) provides for a similar prohibition of publication of evidence or information in proceedings for the recovery of pecuniary penalties.

The purpose of the amendment referred to in clause 7 of the Bill is to enable the Director, with the approval of the Attorney-General or a person authorised in writing by the Attorney-General, to employ persons under term contracts. The terms and conditions of such persons are subject to the approval of the Public Service Board.

The amendment provided for in clause 8 removes certain controls from the Director's capacity to engage consultants and other contractors for services. On 2 July 1984 the Public Service Board notified all Departments and authorities that they should make decisions to engage consultants and other contractors for services without reference to the Board within the financial limits set out in the Budget process for such expenditure. Since the date of the notification Departmental Secretaries have been responsible for the engagement of consultants and other contractors for services without reference to the Board. The amendment removes the requirement that the engagement of consultants by the Director be approved by the Attorney-General or a person authorised by the Attorney-General in writing for that purpose. Clause 8 of the Bill introduced into the House of Representatives contained a further amendment removing an additional requirement that the terms and conditions of such engagements be approved by the Public Service Board. However, an identical amendment was made to the Act in the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill 1985 which secured passage through the Parliament late in 1985. Accordingly, this further amendment was deleted in the House of Representatives and is not before the the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION BILL 1985HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1985HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985AUSTRALIAN BILL OF RIGHTS BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 20 February.
HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION BILL 1985
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of questions that I would like to put to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who is at the table, with regard to the powers residing in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to investigate the infringement by State legislation of rights listed in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I point out that the Covenant is, in fact, appended to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill. I want to clarify whether HREOC has the power to operate independently in investigating the infringement by a State bureaucracy or by State legislation of any of the rights stipulated in the Covenant or whether it can act only in conjunction with the Australian Bill of Rights and therefore is in a position to act on any infringement by the States only after the Australian Bill of Rights has been passed?

—Before I call the Minister I should make it clear that when the Committee last met it resolved to take the four Bills separately. We are considering the first Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill. The question before the Committee is that the Bill stand as printed.
—That does not render in- operable my question?
—No, I am only clarifying what your question is related to, Senator.
—It is relating to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill.
—Mr Chairman--
—A simple yes or no will do, Minister.

—Senator Haines ought to be well aware by now that that is congenitally impossible, not least because of the formidable sophistication with which questions are asked by her in this place. The first point to appreciate is that the Human Rights Commission has no jurisidiction at the moment to investigate actual practices of State governments--
—That is the Human Rights Commission as it stands now?
—As it stands now it has no such jurisdiction under the Covenant.
—We know that.
—We don't know that at all. I don't agree with that.

—The honourable senator may not agree with it, but so far as the State is concerned the situation that will exist when the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is established by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill that is before us now is no different. However, when the Australian Bill of Rights is enacted with its companion piece, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill, the States will be able to be the subject of investigation by the Commission for breaches by their laws of the Bill of Rights. The definition of human rights in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill will change with the enactment of the Bill of Rights, so that the investigation will be of breaches of the Bill of Rights, rather than breaches directly of the Covenant.
—Is that the case notwithstanding that there is an appendage, a Schedule, or whatever one wants to call it, to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill?
— The Covenant is there at the moment because the jurisdiction of the Commission is couched in terms of breaches of human rights, with human rights being defined by reference to the Covenant.
—Which is appended to the Bill.

—It is appended to the Bill. After the Bill of Rights Bill is passed, there will be a further amendment to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act, as it will be by then, to change the definition of human rights to make that definition not one by reference to the Covenant itself but rather to the Covenant rights as picked up by and made into domestic law by the Bill of Rights itself. The idea was to create two quite separate and distinct pieces of legislation which could stand or fall separately. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, by itself, will have jurisdiction by reference to the Covenant, at least so far as Commonwealth and Territory acts and practices are concerned. When the Bill of Rights is enacted as a separate piece of legislation, the definition of human rights will be changed in the way in which I have indicated and the Covenant will be removed from the appendix to the HREOC Bill.
—What is it there for now?

—It is there now because the definition of human rights, which is the subject of HREOC's jurisdiction, is a definition which is based on the Covenant. But after the Bill of Rights is passed and proclaimed into law, that definition of human rights, by reference to the raw text of the Covenant, will no longer be necessary because we will have a definition of human rights that can be based on the terms of the Bill of Rights. Although the Bill of Rights is, of course, in turn based on the Covenant-it must be for constitutional reasons-it will avoid confusion and uncertainty of having two sets of formulated general guarantees, having the Covenant still in existence as a source of jurisdiction when one has the Bill of Rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that the Australian Bill of Rights is putting into effect through legislation the requirement under Part II, Article 2, paragraph 2 of the International Covenant, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where not already provided for by existing legislative or other measures, each State Party to the present Covenant undertakes to take the necessary steps, in accordance with its constitutional processes and with the provisions of the present Covenant, to adopt such legislative or other measures as may be necessary to give effect to the rights recognized in the present Covenant.

All I want to know is whether it is an essential requirement that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission have the Bill to refer to or whether the Covenant itself will be satisfied if the other measures it refers to in Part II Article 2 paragraph 2 include the Schedule remaining in the HREOC Bill-that is, simply to allow it to have a look at infringements of rights.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has no jurisdiction in relation to a State, whether under the Covenant or anything else, under the HREOC Bill that is now before us. HREOC will acquire a jurisdiction in relation to the States after the enactment of the Bill of Rights Bill and the consequential amending Bill that goes with it. When that Bill is enacted later on, HREOC will have acquired a jurisdiction in relation to the States for breaches of `human rights'. But the human rights breaches by a State that it will be able to examine at that stage will be human rights as articulated in the articles of the Bill of Rights, rather than as articulated in the terms of the Covenant.

—The Minister said a few minutes ago that the Human Rights Commission as it currently stands does not have the right to make these sorts of inquiries at the State level. I remind the Minister-or tell him, if he did not already know it-that the Queensland division of the Australian Democrats lodged a complaint with the present Human Rights Commission about the Queensland electoral laws. It was not told by the HRC that the HRC did not have jurisdiction. It was told that the inquiry would be a lengthy one and therefore it did not have the time, the staff, the money or whatever to undertake such an inquiry into State laws.

—I think the source of the confusion here-it may also have informed Senator Missen's interjection earlier-is the different capacity which the existing Human Rights Commission has, and which the new Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will also have, to advise the Commonwealth Attorney-General as to what initiatives or what changes to the law it should make that are within its constitutional power to enact in order to improve the condition of liberty or whatever. It is not a power to investigate complaints about acts or practices. The existing Human Rights Commission has a power to initiate recommendations based on perceived deficiencies in State law. I should have made that statement part of my original answer. That does not refer to a response to a complaint, but it is the kind of investigation of a State law which the honourable senator might well have in mind in the context, I suppose, of electoral laws, but not electoral practices, in the States. On the basis of the existing Human Rights Commission Act, which is in turn based on the language of the Covenant, or on the basis of the new Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act, which is in turn based on the Covenant, one could embark upon some inquiry under that generalised jurisdiction into perceived deficiencies in State law. But that would not be the same as a formalised investigation into practices relying upon the particular, direct and immediate jurisdiction that is newly vested by this legislation.

—The purpose of my interjection was to say that my understanding is that it was argued at the time when the previous Act came into existence that there was a power, even though it was an implied power, in the Commission to look at State laws insofar as it could compare one with another and recommend Federal laws, but not to look at acts and practices or breaches of human rights. That seems to be expanded. That was the point I was making by way of interjection.

—In accepting, at least for the moment, the response that the Minister has given, there still remains the problem that the current Human Rights Commission argued that an inquiry into Queensland's electoral laws would be a lengthy one and therefore, presumably, it would take quite a while to issue a report. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already answered that question as best I can when I said that, in my view, there may still be some residual technically available capacity to rely directly on some part of the terms of the Covenant without the apparatus of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and, for that matter, the Bill of Rights itself, being employed. We are getting into very difficult constitutional waters here. The power under section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution to legislate with respect to external affairs is not simply to legislate on any subject matter that captures the Commonwealth's fancy from time to time. It is a power to legislate for the genuine domestic implementation of an international treaty obligation or some other form of international obligation which may not be necessarily couched in the form of a treaty. The Commonwealth undoubtedly much enhances the chances of any of its legislation surviving constitutionally if that legislation takes place in a context which is clearly and unequivocally one of the domestic implementation of an international treaty obligation. It is not a matter, as we are constantly accused of being enthusiastic about doing, of going around the world and looking at a number of multilateral treaties and bilateral treaties to which we may have become party over a period of several decades and plucking particular heads of power out of those treaties like baubles off a Christmas tree in order to embark upon some legislative adventure which would not otherwise be open to us.
—That would not wash constitutionally anyway, would it?

—That is what I am saying. Quite apart from our desire as a government not to behave in any way that could be objectionable or colourable to men of good will and legal propriety, that sort of exercise would run the risk, constitutionally speaking, of falling on its face. What we do must be and must be seen to be part of an exercise in implementing a genuinely international obligation, and to that extent any exercise in relation to the securing of universal and equal suffrage much improves its chances of success if that exercise takes place in the context of the total legislative exercise, the enactment of a Bill of Rights, and if it takes place in the context of the enforcement mechanism that has been deliberately created to ensure respect for the Covenant and for those rights in the Bill of Rights.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are relying directly on a section of the Bill of Rights which in turn relies on the Covenant, and if we are relying as a precondition to the legislation on the machinery created deliberately by the Parliament to enhance our capacity to implement international obligations and so on, it seems to me that we are also enhancing the ultimate chances of survival. That is a very long way of making what is a quite short point. We may be able to legislate directly on suffrage issues based on particular language of particular clauses in particular treaties, but we have a much better chance of doing so at the end of the day if we follow the course and the sequence of events that the Commonwealth has proposed.

—Some of the responses of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) have evoked in my mind further doubts about the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission which I believe need to be clarified. I refer to the schedules to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill with which we are dealing at the Committee stage.

—They are at pages 34 onwards. Schedule 2 is the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Schedule 3 is the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. The reason for its disappearing from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act, as it would then be, and its being part of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill Act is that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission would no longer retain a jurisdiction to investigate directly complaints or whatever based on breaches of the Covenant. The HREOC jurisdiction would be to respond to complaints or inquiries based on the Bill of Rights itself, the reason being the essentially practical one that if we have an international covenant setting out certain rights with all sorts of qualifications and language and beside it we have a charter of rights in the Bill of Rights Act itself, employing slightly different language at relevant places with the qualifications slightly differently expressed--
—That is the nub, isn't it?

—We will come to the reasons for each one of those changes when we get, mercifully soon I hope, to the Bill of Rights Bill. There are good reasons for that. Having gone down that track of writing a charter of rights in succinct language that will serve all the functions that we want it to serve in a domestic context, but we would strongly argue still picking up and being wholly legitimate in constitutional terms by virtue of that relationship with the covenant, rather than having those two things lying side by side in that way, which would generate confusion, we have taken the view that it is wholly preferable for the HREOC to have its jurisdiction confined to the Bill of Rights itself. —I think the Minister has gone to the nub of the matter. Is the Government going to take it out of the Bill or not? Secondly, the Minister, in his explanation, has admitted that the articles in the Schedule to the Australian Bill of Rights Bill are in some way different from those of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. If they were not different, there would be no confusion if the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights were retained as a schedule to what will be the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act. The Minister has clearly told us that it must come out of that Act because unless it does come out there will be confusion, presumably on the part of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, as to what are and what are not human rights. We were told by the Minister in answer to Senator Haines that from here on out human rights will be as provided not in the articles of the International Covenant but in the articles in the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. He knows as well as I do, because we have both looked at those articles, that they are different. The proof may be found in his statement that Schedule 2 will have to come out of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act because if it does not there will be confusion in the minds of the members of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission as to the interpretation of human rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The first group of Bills is the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. That is a completely self-contained package of legislation. The other self-contained package of legislation is the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and its companion piece, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill, a quite small Bill. The sole purpose of that accompanying Bill, the fourth one that I mentioned, is to remove Schedule 2 from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act and to make clear that the definition of human rights for the purposes of the operation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act is human rights as defined in the Bill of Rights rather than human rights as defined by reference to the Covenant. It has all been there.

It was originally anticipated that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission would be in force, in operation some time before the Bill of Rights itself for one reason or another was in force. It was envisaged that HREOC could best operate if there were maximum continuity between it and the existing Human Rights Commission, with the same jurisdiction in relation to the Covenant and referring to the same language in the Covenant as was previously the case. Now it is very likely, with the two groups of Bills going through together, that it would not have been necessary to deal with this in this way. I think Senator Harradine can understand the logical sequence that is involved.

We have added the expression `the right to marry a person of the opposite sex'. Senator Harradine cannot have it both ways. It is a little rugged for him to argue that there needs to be this clarification in the language of the Bill of Rights because of the alleged ambiguity or whatever of the Covenant and then triumphantly to claim that there is now some fundamental difference of a possibly sinister kind between the language of the charter and the language of the Covenant. There is no intention for there to be any difference in substance; the only difference is of form, in each case for good reasons, and we will explain those reasons, no doubt during the Committee debate of each one of these clauses.

to examine enactments, and (when requested to do so by the Minister) propose enactments, for the purpose of ascertaining whether the enactments or proposed enactments, as the case may be, are, or would be, inconsistent with or contrary to any human right, and to report to the Minister the results of any such examination;

These amendments relate specifically to the membership of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I remind the Committee that under section 7 of the Human Rights Commission Act the present Human Rights Commission consists of a Chairman and a Deputy Chairman and not less than five or more than nine members. The nine members may be part time members. During the period for which the Commission has operated there have been a substantial number of members-I think five or six-who have operated as part time members, who have operated, I think, effectively and usefully and who have been quite instrumental, in various ways, in taking an interest in various aspects of various reports and in checking reports under preparation by members of the staff of the Commission. Although I suppose at times their keenness and interest may not always have been appreciated by staff members, I think they have been very valuable in keeping the Commission on an even keel and, I suppose, in keeping the organisation from being a totally bureaucratic organisation, which it would otherwise be.

As I remember, the Bill which the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), as Attorney-General, was proposing before the last election proposed that part time commissioners were to be abolished altogether. However, in this Bill one will see that the part time commissioners are reduced to as little as one. Clause 8 of the Bill states:
(1) the Commission shall consist of-
(a) a President;
(b) the Race Discrimination Commissioner;
(c) the Sex Discrimination Commissioner; and
(d) at least one other member but not more than 3 other members.

Some of those other members can be part time. However, we could now have the situation in which the Commission will be almost totally-if I can say so-bureaucratic and the full time members will totally dominate the Commission. The part time member or the one other member who may belong to the Commission could have no real significance. Therefore, the amendment which I have moved and which I believe will have the support of the Opposition and, I trust, the support of other sections of the Senate deals basically with three things. In the first place it amends paragraph (d) so that instead of stating `at least one other member but not more than 3 other members' it states:

(d) 3 members who shall be persons who, from their experience in non-government representational groups, minority groups or social service organisations, have specialist knowledge and experience in human rights activities;
I then go on to add another category (e) which states:

(e) 3 other members who shall be persons nominated biennially by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General to represent the States, being persons of knowledge and experience in human rights acts and practices.

I think basically that is a continuation of the present situation except, of course, there will be precisely three commissioners from non-government organisations and three representing the States. Those State commissioners, one presumes, will rotate. The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General will decide that such and such a State is to be represented on the Commission for two years and that some other State is to be represented later on. They would be people who are knowledgeable in this area and, therefore, not people who just go to make up numbers. In the first place these would be people who would contribute their knowledge as non-government organisational members who are concerned with human rights, and in the second place they would be people from the States who know the particular problems of their own and other States and who will bring that experience to bear in discussions which take place.

If we are to have a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission-it does appear, by noting the numbers in this chamber, that that is going to happen-it ought to be a body which is fairly representative and, therefore one which, if it is going to look into any aspect of State laws or State positions, ought to comprise people who have some knowledge of or can be approached and told the position by the States and therefore are representatives in that sense. That is the basic structure which I propose in this amendment. Much of the rest of this amendment is consequential. It provides in (1) (d) and (e) that people shall be appointed as part time members. Obviously, it is important that those members should be people not fully engaged in that activity but also engaged in other activities which have been the cause for their appointment to this position. The third part of this structure which I bring in is contained in part 10 of the amendment. It inserts clause (3A), which states:

Between meetings of the Commission the President may, at any time, convene a meeting of the full-time members of the Commission which meeting may, subject to the control of the Commission, carry out the day to day affairs of, and perform the functions of, the Commission, and for the purposes of such a meeting of the Commission, and for the purposes of such a meeting of the Commission a quorum is constituted by a number of full-time members that is not less than one-half of the number of full-time members for the time being holding office under section 8.

I regret the somewhat cumbersome nature of that last expression, but I take that from the existing clause which deals with a quorum and which means, of course, that if we have a quorum of a smaller body we need a smaller quorum. The purpose of this is that this would be a Commission of slightly larger numbers than at present and it therefore would be difficult to meet as regularly and as often to deal with the day to day affairs and to carry out the normal functions. I suppose important issues would be deferred until a meeting of the full Commission and this meeting would be subject to the control of the full Commission. I include this clause so it will not lead to the Commission being too cumbersome an organisation but one whose full time members can meet between meetings. I commend to the Senate the structure in these amendments. I suggest that it accords with the Opposition's idea of federalism and the idea that the States should be consulted. It also accords with the belief of, I think, all members of this chamber in the voluntary principle that people who belong to non-government organisations have an important part to play in human rights activities, and that they keep their feet on the ground and will not be carried away by being too close to the heady air of Canberra. They will come here with other members knowing the organisations they belong to and I believe this would strengthen the position of the organisation. It depends on whether the Bill of Rights holds up constitutionally. Without it, the Commission could still stand and play an active role. I believe that a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission which has this type of component on it would be a stronger body, and therefore the amendment should be supported.

I suggest that that particular proposed advisory committee is a much more immediate way of capturing the ongoing involvement of the State Attorneys-General than are the three members of the Commission to whom Senator Missen refers. SPEECH.PARA: The Administrative Appeals Tribunal jurisdiction is not an available or appropriate alternative in this matter. Clause 4 of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is, of course, a definition clause which has a very major impact on the way in which this Bill will operate. It defines the jurisdiction of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission which is established by another Bill. The Bill gives jurisdiction to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in respect of acts and practices which are alleged to breach the provisions of the Australian Bill of Rights as set out in Part II of the Bill. The importance of this point is the extent to which the word `jurisdiction' of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission can relate to acts and practices. In our view the acts and practices should be confined to those of Commonwealth public servants or authorities. However, the Government has seen fit to apply these acts and practices in a much broader way. They are defined to extend to an act which is done by or on behalf of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, an act which is done by or on behalf of an authority of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, or an act which is done in relation to Australian citizens, either within or outside Australia.

We believe that there is far too wide an application of acts or practices in this Bill of Rights for reasons which I have already given elsewhere. But if the Bill is to be defined in this very broad way-namely, to apply to acts and practices by people acting on behalf of the Commonwealth Government or of a State or a Territory, or practices by authorities of those bodies-we believe that it should extend to the acts or practices done by or on behalf of a trade union or a body corporate. It is notorious that in this day and age the average person whose human rights may be in question may be affected not only by government but also by corporations or trade unions. Under this Government, in particular, we are living in an age not only of big government but also of big unions and big business. If acts, practices, enactments and legislatures and so on, at both the Commonwealth and State level, are to be judged in accordance with their conformity with the Bill of Rights, other major institutions in the society in which we live are equally required to be, and ought to be, judged in the same way. As I said, we could be saddled with a Bill of Rights to which we are completely opposed and which we will continue to vote against. However, if we are going to have a Bill of Rights and a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to protect the rights of individuals in this country, it is as well for us to recognise that the rights of individuals are constantly being affected by trade unions and big corporations, not just by government.

The Mudginberri dispute last year in the Northern Territory involved a small group of people working in an abattoir who reached an agreement with their employer about the terms and conditions under which they were going to work. As the agreement was within the award that was laid down by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the claim could not be made that the parties were operating outside of the Commission. Under that agreement the employees were working satisfactorily and getting better conditions and pay than would have been applied under the award. This small group of people was then bludgeoned by government-the Government failed to do its duty, and the High Court of Australia has now decided that the Government failed to do its duty-and severely bludgeoned by a trade union which picketed the operation. The Government gave in in a most disgraceful way. That was an example of individuals in this country badly needing some protection. They needed protection against a trade union and they needed protection against a government.

I do not know whether the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission legislation or the Australian Bill of Rights would have advanced the position of these people. Certainly some legislation which had been put on the statute books by the Fraser Government did help them. If we are to put on the statute books of this country a Bill of Rights which guarantees the rights of individuals and advances the individuals' rights and human rights in this country, those rights may be just as likely challenged, threatened, taken away or modified in some way by the activities of trade unions and, unfortunately, also by big business or big corporations.

We know where threats come from. They usually come from combinations or organisations. One might say: `Oh well, perhaps one individual may be badly affected by another individual'. But, historically, governments are certainly a major threat as far as real dangers to human rights are concerned. In the society in which we live those threats are likely to come from big combinations of power, not only government, and particularly trade unions. Threats may also come from large corporations acting in combination against individuals. Laws such as the Trade Practices Act have done something about these things. Of course, we as an Opposition think that is the proper way to go. This Parliament tackles these matters when new forms of danger to individuals arise from time to time. We think the proper way to go is to use the legislation which is available to us.

Unfortunately the Senate voted to give the Bill a second reading and we may yet have a Bill of Rights included in our legal system. What sort of a Bill of Rights is it if it is going to protect people against only one form of overweening power, namely that of government, and when other big groupings of people in this country can exercise overweening power against individuals? This Government is not really interested in human rights. It has a cosmetic desire to pander to a small group of people that it thinks is influential. It wants to mollify that group by proceeding with this Bill of Rights. This Bill of Rights is not going to be of much use at all. If the Government was really interested in preserving the rights of individuals it would recognise this fact. It has failed to do so. We believe that the Government should be confronted with the reality of the world and society in which we are living. We have moved the amendments in an attempt to expand the operation of the guarantees in this Bill of Rights beyond that of people in their dealings with government to people in their dealings with trade unions or corporations.

The Opposition is concerned about the application of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill to Norfolk Island because of the particular constitutional status of Norfolk Island and the peculiarities of it. Very strong representations have been made by the Government of that Territory not just to the Opposition but to this Parliament. The Opposition feels that there is great substance in the matters that have been put to it. Norfolk Island has limited self-government under the Norfolk Island Act, which was passed by this Parliament in 1979. If I remember rightly, that was as a result of a royal commission of inquiry into the administration of Norfolk Island and the nature of the constitutional framework which it should enjoy as a territory with special status in relation to Australia.

The island, of course, is a small one with a population of only 1,950 people. The pressure on land use in Norfolk Island and the composition of its population are matters of very grave concern to the inhabitants of that island. Norfolk Island residents, as we know, do not vote in Australian elections. In order to qualify to vote in Norfolk Island elections residence is required for a continuous period of three years. Also, people have to have the intention to live their indefinitely. Norfolk Island has legislation to control permanent residence. It has an immigration Act which was assented to by the Governor-General of the Commonwealth, under the present Government, in March 1984. That control of migration to Norfolk Island applies to Australian citizens as well as to foreigners. I think Australians may be regarded virtually as foreigners in that Territory. If I may say so, that has been accepted by this Parliament in the legislation I have referred to and was approved of by this Government as recently as March 1984. Australian and Norfolk Islanders do not pay Australian taxes on their Norfolk Island-sourced income, and fortunately for us their Government has financial self-sufficiency.

As I said, there are some very peculiar features of the relationship between Australia and Norfolk Island. The concern in the Territory is that these arrangements, which really go to the heart of the society of Norfolk Island, namely the control of people being able to reside there permanently and the control of their electoral system, and which give rights to residents of a permanent character may well be challenged if this Bill of Rights were applied to them, particularly the right guaranteeing freedom of movement. One of the articles clearly guarantees freedom of movement. The immigration Act to which I referred would seem likely to be struck down as being not in conformity with that piece of Territory legislation. Clearly, from the description I have given of the size and nature of the island and the society on it, unrestricted immigration would cause a complete change to the character of the society, and indeed of the island. As I have said, there is perhaps not quite the same likelihood, but there is a concern and there is a possibility that its electoral laws would be affected by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The Norfolk Island Public Service is restricted to permanent residents of the island as part of the general policy of Norfolk Island to maintain the cohesiveness of the society which it has enjoyed for centuries.

For this combination of reasons, the Chief Minister and other Ministers have made representations to the Opposition, which the Opposition has studied and believes have merit. For those reasons we are moving these amendments to exclude Norfolk Island from the ambit of the Bill, the same as the Bill excludes the Northern Territory, except in relation to the matters we have already debated.

This Bill, because of federalist principles, is said not to apply to the States. Of course, we know perfectly well that that guarantee of the Government is false and misleading. The Government, despite those factors, is claiming that this Bill is in accordance with federal principles. The fact that the Government's proposal excludes the Northern Territory emphasises the fact that we are observing the Federal principles, because the Northern Territory is a self-governing Territory. Norfolk Island may not be as fully self-governing as the Northern Territory; nonetheless, it has a real measure of self-government and it has these social peculiarities I have described, which I believe should be decided by the Norfolk Island legislature. If the laws which have been passed, which I have described, cannot be passed the whole nature of the island and its social life probably will be irreparably damaged.

On the principle that the Government has decided to exclude the Northern Territory-it says it excludes the States, although we know that indirectly this Bill will be used against the States; but that is another part of the debate-we believe that it would be appropriate for Norfolk Island to be excluded as well.

Having come fresh from a discussion with the Canadian Chief Justice a few weeks ago about this, I think I can say that with some confidence. The particular language talks in terms of such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society. There are all sorts of limitations that may well be construed in context as reasonable. Article 15 of the Australian Bill of Rights, dealing with the freedom of movement, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Every person lawfully in Australia has the right to freedom of movement and choice of residence.

That must be already, for the general run of the mill Australian, subject to reasonable limitations and not subject to be construed absolutely, otherwise local government zoning laws as to areas that could properly be the subject of residence would have no chance of surviving the slings and arrows of the Bill of Rights in the court. Of course there are limitations of all kinds on most of these rights which are going to have to be acknowledged, accepted and understood. There will be room for argument around the edges.

In the particular context of Norfolk Island, I think there is ample room for argument about the application of Article 3 should anyone choose to litigate it in this context. I further made the point-I mentioned it indirectly in my opening remarks and I will mention it more directly now-that in a letter of 2 January 1986 to the Chief Minister of Norfolk Island the Attorney-General confirmed that he, in a previous discussion with the Chief Minister, undertook that if the operation of the Bill of Rights resulted in jeopardy to the existing legal arrangements in the areas of local immigration-he mentioned one or two other matters-he would support the enactment of specific overriding conditions if necessary. That is one of the options available under the Bill of Rights, enacted as it is as an ordinary Act of parliament and capable of amendment and of limitation in that way. That is one of the reasons-the need to tread carefully in some of those areas-that we have all along opposed the immediate introduction and application of a constitutional Bill of Rights, unamendable for all practical purposes and potentially overreaching in some of its applications.

I say all of that to make the point that there may be some appropriate exceptions as far as Norfolk Island is concerned which are cheerfully acknowledged by the Government. But there are many other areas of application of the basic guarantees which are and must be regarded as in principle equally applicable to the citizens of Norfolk Island as they are to other Australians. Against that background I think it is perfectly reasonable for the Government to take the view that Norfolk Island should be subject to the basic operation of the Bill. I repeat that I hope the amendments will be rejected accordingly.
