It is just another demonstration of the flexibility with which the Government is approaching this matter in order to keep as many people satisfied as possible.

—I do not think anybody is arguing about whether the Committee is entitled to have that piece of paper tabled. We are, I think, discussing whether we can find some process by which to give the Minister time to seek approval from the two people he has mentioned he would want approval from and not stop us from continuing to consider the Bill. —Mr Chairman, that is quite unsatisfactory to the Opposition and to me. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Nuclear Activities (Prohibitions) Ordinance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 22 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why has the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Nuclear Activities (Prohibitions) Ordinance, which was passed by the ACT House of Assembly on 17 April 1984, not been presented to the Federal Parliament.

(2) When will the Government be acting on its commitments by enforcing the ACT Nuclear Activities (Prohibitions) Ordinance on behalf of the people of the ACT, given the Government's commitment to disarmament, and its recent support for the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following answer has been provided to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The proposal passed by the ACT House of Assembly on 17 April 1984 will not be presented to the Federal Parliament as it is in conflict with both Government policy and Australia's international treaty obligations.

The Government is committed to ensuring that Australia remains a nuclear weapons free country, both under the terms of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, and the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

The Government has decided that, in line with its obligation under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, the trade in uranium for peaceful purposes and the use of radioactive materials in medical and other research activities will not be prohibited. The declaration of the ACT as a nuclear free zone as envisaged by the Assembly's proposal could hinder such activities within the ACT.

(2) Given the above, the Government will be taking no further action in relation to the Assembly's proposal. The Government does, however, remain committed to disarmament as is demonstrated by our membership of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and our central role in the formation of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have detailed reports been received by the Australian Government on the November Geneva Summit talks held between United States' President Reagan, and Soviet leader Gorbachev; and if so, and after detailed analysis by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Prime Minister, and the Cabinet, could the Minister inform the Senate at the earliest possible date of what the ramifications are to Australia.
(2) Will the result of the talks have any effect on-
(a) the ANZUS Treaty;
(b) Australian-American relations;
(c) Australian-USSR relations;
(d) Australia's policy for disarmament; and
(e) the prospects for a lasting, enduring world peace.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government was briefed by the United States and the Soviet Union on the outcome of the summit talks between President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev. The Prime Minister, the Minister for Defence and I were personally briefed on the summit talks by the special emissary of President Reagan, Allan Holmes, Director, Politico-Military Affairs in the State Department. I was also briefed by the Soviet Ambassador.

As I stated publicly at the time following the summit talks the outcome was better than most of us hoped for and in realistic terms as much as we could have expected. I also said that I could not see any change in Australia's relationship with either the Soviet Union or the United States arising from the summit talks. The summit talks do not affect the ANZUS Treaty, Australia-United States relations, Australia-USSR relations nor Australia's policy in the disarmament area.

President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev agreed in their joint statement that a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought and emphasised the importance of preventing any war between them, nuclear or conventional. They also agreed to accelerate work on the Geneva arms talks with a view to accomplishing the tasks set down in the Joint US-Soviet Agreement of January 1985 of preventing an arms race in space and to terminate it on earth, limiting and reducing nuclear arms and enhancing strategic stability. Both leaders also called for early progress in areas where there is common ground, including the principle of a 50 per cent reduction in the nuclear arms of both countries, appropriately applied, and the idea of an interim INF agreement. Australia welcomed this outcome and believes that attainment of these objectives would establish the basis for a lasting, enduring world peace.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 26 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister for Health take urgent action following complaints from people, particularly in the Bundaberg region regarding delays in hearing test appointments by the National Acoustic Laboratories, which are apparently now 7 months, to ensure the situation is improved, and will he outline measures he will take towards this end.
(2) What are the best and most advantageous procedures the deaf can take to gain the earliest possible advice and assistance.
(3) Has there been any improvement in services to the deaf since Senator Jones first raised this matter on 24 March 1982 when the previous Fraser Government was in office.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have been concerned for some time about prolonged waiting times, due to heavy demand for National Acoustic Laboratories (NAL) services throughout Australia, and have taken action to address this problem. Additional staff resources have been made available and it is intended that average waiting times at all permanent NAL centres around Australia will be reduced to a maximum of 3 months by the end of June 1986. Waiting times at all visiting NAL centres will be reduced to a similar maximum waiting time, except where the demand for service is so small that visits are only made at intervals greater than 3 months, and clients are unable to travel to a larger centre.

At Bundaberg, 26 new pensioner cases currently waiting will all be seen during the next regular visit to that centre in February 1986. Future visits to this centre are planned for every 2 months for the remainder of this year. Accommodation at the centre has recently been improved by establishing a fixed centre with sound proof test facilities. This will enable the quality and standard of service provided to clients in the area to be upgraded.

(2) Persons who suspect that they may have a hearing problem should, in the first instance, consult their doctor who will advise regarding treatment or referral. Advice as to whether they may be eligible for NAL hearing assistance, is available to persons who contact a NAL Hearing Centre, or a specialised welfare organisation. For those who cannot attend a hearing centre, many hospitals throughout Australia have audiology clinics which offer advice and assistance. All persons under 21 years of age with hearing problems are eligible for NAL assistance and do not require a doctor's referral.
(3) Since 1983 there have been a number of improvements in services to the deaf. These improvements are:
new hearing aid selection procedures resulting in improved hearing aid use;

a range of better hearing aids and services, such as vibrotactile aids for profoundly deaf persons; purchase of commercial FM systems for issue to children; free repair of privately owned FM systems; and free battery issues for cochlear implants;

more satisfactory services to country clients throughout Australia by providing 6 new permanent hearing centres in rural areas (5 more centres outside the capital cities are planned) and more frequent visiting services;
recruitment and training of additional staff to overcome waiting time problems, particularly in Queensland, South Australia, West Australia and Tasmania;
a new NAL building at Chatswood, with $1 million provided to fit out research facilities, expected to be opened in March 1986;
a feasibility study of a proposal for the manufacture of hearing aids in Australia by private industry.

In addition, hearing research funding provided through the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) has to date resulted in the development of the cochlear implant prosthesis (Bionic Ear) for the profoundly deaf.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 November 1985:

(3) Under sub-clause 23 (6) of the Act what limits are there to the imposition of conditions by the Minister and what appeal procedures are there.

(4) Why was it not the preferred procedure to make a revocation a further function of the Court if sub-clause 27 (8) allows the licensing authority to revoke a disqualification after the Court has been given the power to disqualify.
(5) Who is to keep the Register under sub-clause 31 (4)-each State, one State, the advisory body, the Federal Department or some new body, and at whose expense will the registry be maintained.

A decision under sub-paragraph 15 (4) (b) (ii) would be subject to review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 (`the AD (JR) Act').
(2) No. The allocation of payments under sub-section 23 (3) of the Act would be subject to review under the AD (JR) Act.

(3) Conditions imposed under sub-section 23 (6) of the Act must be relevant and for the purposes of the Act. The imposition of conditions under sub-section 23 (6) would be subject to review under the AD (JR) Act.

(4) Sub-section 27 (8) provides that a licensing authority may only revoke a disqualification where, under sub-section 27 (7), a court has specified a date after which a disqualified operator may apply for revocation. Accordingly, revocation was considered to be an administrative function and more appropriately performed by a licensing authority. In effect, a licensing authority would be acting as a parole board in this situation.
A decision made by a licensing authority under sub-section 27 (8) is reviewable under section 51 of the Act.

(5) A central register would be established by the Federal Department of Transport and maintained on the basis of information supplied by the States and Territories. Any costs associated with the register will be met from within the financial allocations to the Department.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 3 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a capital city bias in the newspaper advertising practices of a majority of Federal Government Departments and statutory authorities, which means that announcements of financial grants and government inquiries rarely appear in non-metropolitan newspapers.

(2) Does this discriminatory practice virtually ignore a significant section of the Australian community, whose members are unaware of fundamental government information and availability of financial assistance.

(3) How does the Government disseminate information and can the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism undertake to have current procedures reviewed to ensure that up to one-third of taxpayers are not expected to pay for advertising which fails to recognise regional Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is usually some bias towards the mass-circulation metropolitan newspapers, reflecting the fact that they reach the largest numbers of the target audiences. The Government nevertheless recognises the importance of non-metropolitan papers to rural dwellers and as a matter of policy, encourages departmental advertisers to include them in advertising schedules. The degree to which they are included is, however, influenced by the availability of departmental funds.

The types of advertising cited in the question- announcements of financial grants and government inquiries-are classified as non-campaign advertising which, under the recently revised central advertising system, is arranged by departments and some statutory authorities direct with the Government's master advertising agency for non-campaign advertising, Gordon & Gotch Ltd. Most departments tend to stipulate the selection of newspapers. If non-metropolitan newspapers have not been included and officers of Gordon & Gotch Ltd consider they should have been to reach the desired target audience for the message, then they will recommend this to the departmental advertiser. The decision to include all, some or none of the rural newspapers then rests with the departmental advertiser and a decision which does not favour rural papers is invariably the result of budgetary restrictions. The non-campaign master agency Gordon & Gotch has reported that advertising for financial grants and government inquiries has in recent months favoured the mass circulation metropolitan dailies and national newspapers.

From the start of the revised centralised advertising system on 1 October 1984 to 30 November 1985, departments and authorities spent $9,575,914 on non-campaign advertising in major metropolitan/national newspapers and $699,008 in rural newspapers.
(2) No. The mass circulation metropolitan/national newspapers achieve substantial penetration into rural markets.

(3) Ministers are individually responsible for information programs relating to government programs and policies within their portfolio. Co-ordination mechanisms are in place to help ensure that the information activities are properly planned and fit within the broad objectives of the government. The basis of selection of media for such campaigns or notices is to determine the most efficient, cost effective means of reaching the highest possible numbers of the desired target audience, having regard for the nature of the message. Recognising, however, the importance of local newspapers to rural dwellers, the Government has a policy, administered by the Information Co-ordination branch of the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, which encourages the use of provincial press in departmental advertising campaigns or notices.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November 1985 (Hansard, page 2359) Senator Durack asked the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the view expressed by the Attorney-General yesterday that `it would be appropriate' to use the Bill of Rights legislation to change the electoral systems of Western Australia and Queensland. I also refer the Minister to the comment by Premier Burke of Western Australia that his Government had always maintained that the matter should be dealt with in Western Australia; in other words, by the State . . .

I ask the Minister: Do the views expressed by the Attorney-General represent a decision of the Federal Government? Does the Minister agree that any changes to State electoral laws should be dealt with by the electors in the States and not by the Federal Parliament?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

As the Attorney-General pointed out in his Second Reading Speech relating to the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985, the Bill will not override State laws. This is because the Government hopes to achieve if possible a co-operative approach to human rights protection. Certainly, it would be preferable for the Western Australian Parliament itself to effect the electoral reforms that are so badly needed in respect of the Legislative Council in that State.

Senators will be aware, however, that despite a number of attempts by the Government of Western Australia to effect those reforms, the gross disparities in the number of voters in different electorates for the Legislative Council remain. All attempts at reform, even those seeking to resolve the issue through a referendum, have been rejected by the Opposition in the Legislative Council.

Senators will recall the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs that the provision in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which guarantees ``universal and equal suffrage'' (see Art. 6 (b) of the Bill of Rights) is ``so fundamental that it should not be subject to displacement by any State.'' The Government has much sympathy for this view, since electoral discrepancies of the kind that exist in Western Australia represent the gravest imposition on the most basic political rights of the citizen. However the Government takes the view that, even in this important area, State law should not be overridden until the relevant State Government or, in the case of Western Australia, the relevant State Opposition, has had an opportunity, following the enactment of the Bill of Rights, to amend the law so as to give full and proper effect to this most basic civil right.

Finally, I note that the Attorney-General said in his Second Reading Speech that, if action on the part of the States to remedy legislation which is shown to breach the Bill of Rights is not forthcoming, the Commonwealth reserves the right to enact specific overriding Commonwealth legislation, and to extend the operation of the Bill of Rights to the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 December 1985 (Hansard, page 3176) Senator Durack asked me, as the Minister representing the Attorney-General, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to reports that have been attributed to a spokesperson for the Attorney-General that the Government has decided on the membership of the commission to prepare a new Constitution for Australia, presumably by 1988. Is the chairman of the Commission Sir Maurice Byers, the former Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth? Will other members of the commission include, among others, former Prime Minister Whitlam and the former Premier of Victoria, Sir Rupert Hamer? Can the Minister say who would be the greater proponent for increased power for the Commonwealth at the expense of the States, Mr Whitlam or Sir Maurice Byers? Has Sir Rupert Hamer been selected as the sole representative of the interests of the States on this commission? Will the product of this commission, whatever it comes up with, be referred to the Australian Constitutional Convention, directly to the people or just to the waste paper basket?
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The inaugural meeting of the Constitutional Commission was held on 31 January 1986 in Sydney. The terms of reference of the Commission are:
`To inquire into and report on or before 30 June 1988 on the revision of the Australian Constitution to:
(a) adequately reflect Australia's status as an independent nation and a Federal Parliamentary democracy;
(b) provide the most suitable framework for the economic, social and political development of Australia as a federation;
(c) recognise an appropriate division of responsibilities between the Commonwealth, the States self-governing Territories and Local Government; and
(d) ensure that democratic rights are guaranteed.'

The Commission is chaired by Sir Maurice Byers, the former Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth, and includes five other distinguished members-the former Prime Minister Mr Whitlam, QC, the former Victorian Premier, Sir Rupert Hamer, Mr Justice Toohey of the Federal Court of Australia, Professor Leslie Zines of the Australian National University and Professor Enid Campbell of Monash University. Each member brings a wealth of knowledge and experience in constitutional matters to the Commission.
Sir Maurice Byers was Commonwealth Solicitor-General from 1974 to 1984 and played an important role in constitutional developments during this period.

Mr Whitlam has a long-standing commitment to constitutional reform and unique experience as Prime Minister at a time when Commonwealth legislation survived nearly all High Court challenges but the machinery of government and constitutional conventions came under great stress.
Sir Rupert Hamer was instrumental, as Victorian Premier, in establishing the Australian Constitutional Convention in 1973. He has taken a keen interest since then in constitutional review.

Mr Justice Toohey of the Federal Court of Australia was Aboriginal Land Commissioner for the Northern Territory from 1977 to 1982 and also had a distinguished career at the Western Australian Bar prior to his appointment as a Federal Court Judge.
Professor Leslie Zines is Dean of the Law Faculty at the Australian National University and is a leading authority on Australian constitutional law.

Professor Enid Campbell of Monash University has written extensively on constitutional and administrative subjects and is currently a member of the Tertiary Education Committee's inquiry into legal education.

The Commission is assisted by five advisory committees comprising prominent Australians who are representative of all sections of the community. It is expected that they will make a significant contribution to the work of the Commission. The Commission will also involve the public as well as business, trade unions and financial institutions as much as possible during the course of its inquiry.
It is to be hoped that, given the importance of the task before the Constitutional Commission, a bipartisan approach will prevail.
